choices.text: Narrow cricothyroid space and flat thyroid cartilage
Subglottic narrowing due to smaller diameter of cricoid cartilage
High position of the larynx allowing epiglottis to meet the soft palate
Long and firm laryngeal cartilages resistant to collapse

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the emergency room with inspiratory stridor and difficulty feeding. On examination, the child shows signs of upper airway obstruction. Which of the following anatomical features of the infant larynx is most likely contributing to the simultaneous occurrence of stridor and feeding difficulty?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subglottic narrowing due to smaller diameter of cricoid cartilage

 

In infants, the subglottis is the narrowest part of the airway, as the cricoid cartilage is smaller than the glottis. This contributes to a higher risk of airway obstruction during inflammation or edema, leading to stridor and respiratory distress.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Narrow cricothyroid space and flat thyroid cartilage: This affects tracheostomy access and surgical landmarks, but does not explain stridor or feeding issues.

 

Option C. High position of the larynx allowing epiglottis to meet the soft palate: This anatomical arrangement helps feeding and breathing simultaneously, and prevents aspiration, not causes it.

 

Option D. Long and firm laryngeal cartilages resistant to collapse: In fact, infant cartilages are soft and prone to collapse, which increases the risk of obstruction—not the opposite.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The subglottis is the narrowest part of the infant airway due to the smaller diameter of the cricoid cartilage, making it a common site for airway obstruction and stridor.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 286

choices.text: Blunt trauma from steering wheel impact
Kick to the neck during physical assault

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a high-speed motor vehicle accident. He has hoarseness of voice, anterior neck pain, and subcutaneous emphysema. Imaging reveals disruption in the laryngotracheal framework. Which of the following is the most common cause of such laryngotracheal trauma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blunt trauma from steering wheel impact

 

The most common cause of laryngotracheal trauma is blunt trauma to the neck, particularly in automobile accidents, where the neck strikes the steering wheel or dashboard.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strangulation: Less common cause. May cause laryngeal fracture or soft tissue edema, but it's not the most frequent.

 

Option B. Penetrating gunshot wound: Penetrating injuries are less common than blunt trauma in civilian settings.

 

Option D. Kick to the neck during physical assault: Also a recognized cause, but less frequent compared to motor vehicle accidents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blunt trauma from automobile accidents, especially when the neck strikes the steering wheel, is the most common cause of laryngotracheal injury.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 287

choices.text: Dislocation of cricoarytenoid joint has no impact on vocal cord function
Children are more prone to laryngeal fractures due to soft cartilage
Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury may occur due to cricothyroid joint dislocation
Thyroid cartilage fractures do not affect false vocal cords

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents after a road traffic accident with hoarseness, subcutaneous emphysema in the neck, and inspiratory stridor. On examination, there is tenderness over the thyroid cartilage and crepitus on palpation. Which of the following is most likely true regarding laryngotracheal trauma in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury may occur due to cricothyroid joint dislocation

 

The recurrent laryngeal nerve passes just behind the cricothyroid joint. Dislocation at this joint can injure the nerve, causing vocal cord paralysis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dislocation of cricoarytenoid joint has no impact on vocal cord function: Incorrect. Cricoarytenoid joint dislocation can cause arytenoid displacement, leading to hoarseness, voice change, or airway obstruction due to impaired cord movement.

 

Option B. Children are more prone to laryngeal fractures due to soft cartilage: Incorrect. Children are less prone because their laryngeal cartilages are more resilient and less calcified than adults.

 

Option D. Thyroid cartilage fractures do not affect false vocal cords: Incorrect. Fracture of upper thyroid cartilage may avulse epiglottis and false cords.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dislocation of the cricothyroid joint in laryngeal trauma may injure the recurrent laryngeal nerve, leading to vocal cord paralysis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 287

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident with hoarseness, painful swallowing, and difficulty breathing. On examination, there is tenderness over the anterior neck, flattening of the thyroid prominence, and palpable subcutaneous crepitus that increases with coughing. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laryngotracheal trauma

 

Key features such as hoarseness, odynophagia (painful swallowing), subcutaneous emphysema, and loss of thyroid prominence contour suggest trauma to the larynx or trachea. Flattened thyroid prominence and crepitus between cartilages are classic signs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epiglottitis: Incorrect. Typically presents with drooling, muffled voice, high fever, and stridor in a child or adult. Subcutaneous emphysema and palpable fractures are not features.

 

 

Option C. Retropharyngeal abscess: Incorrect. Common in children, presents with fever, neck stiffness, dysphagia, and bulging of the posterior pharyngeal wall—but not crepitus or cartilage fractures.

 

 

Option D. Peritonsillar abscess: Incorrect. Characterized by unilateral sore throat, uvular deviation, trismus, and muffled voice—does not cause subcutaneous emphysema or thyroid cartilage flattening.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngotracheal trauma presents with hoarseness, painful swallowing, subcutaneous emphysema, and altered neck contour due to cartilage displacement or fracture.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 287

choices.text: Rigid direct laryngoscopy under general anesthesia

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the ER after a motorbike accident with hoarseness, subcutaneous emphysema over the neck, and mild respiratory distress. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals glottic asymmetry and exposed cartilage. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to further assess the extent of laryngeal injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT scan of neck (preferably 3D reconstruction)

 

CT, especially 3D CT, is most valuable in assessing moderate to severe laryngeal trauma. It helps visualize cartilage fractures, mucosal disruptions, and airway patency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI neck: Incorrect. MRI is not the investigation of choice in trauma cases due to longer acquisition time and poor bone/cartilage definition. It is more useful for soft tissue tumors.

 

Option B. Rigid direct laryngoscopy under GA: Incorrect. It may precipitate respiratory compromise in the acute phase. Fibreoptic laryngoscopy is safer and more informative initially. Direct laryngoscopy is now largely replaced by fibreoptic methods.

 

Option D. Barium swallow: Incorrect. Used for suspected esophageal injury. Gastrograffin is preferred over barium due to risk of mediastinitis. Not a first-line modality for laryngeal trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT scan (preferably 3D) is the most valuable imaging modality for assessing moderate to severe laryngotracheal trauma.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 288

choices.text: Immediate surgical exploration of the larynx
Conservative treatment with voice rest, steroids, humidified air, and antibiotics
Observe at home with oral painkillers

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with blunt trauma to the neck after a road traffic accident. He has mild hoarseness and subcutaneous neck emphysema but no stridor or airway compromise. Indirect laryngoscopy shows mild mucosal laceration with supraglottic oedema. He is hemodynamically stable. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Conservative treatment with voice rest, steroids, humidified air, and antibiotics

 

This is the standard approach in stable patients with mild-to-moderate trauma. Steroids help reduce edema, humidified air keeps mucosa moist, and antibiotics prevent perichondritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency tracheostomy: Incorrect. Indicated in severe airway compromise or impending obstruction, which is not present here.

 

Option B. Immediate surgical exploration of the larynx: Incorrect. Not required in minor to moderate injuries without structural disruption or airway compromise.

 

Option D. Observe at home with oral painkillers: Incorrect. Hospital observation is necessary due to the risk of delayed airway obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conservative management of mild laryngotracheal trauma includes hospitalization, voice rest, humidified air, steroids, and antibiotics to prevent complications like oedema, infection, and stenosis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 288

choices.text: Immediate open reduction and plating of thyroid cartilage fracture
Endotracheal intubation followed by conservative management
Surgical repair with open reduction, cartilage wiring, and mucosal repair within 3–5 days
Observation only, as the tracheostomy is already done

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents 24 hours after sustaining blunt trauma to the neck in a bike accident. He has hoarseness, subcutaneous emphysema, and CT shows a displaced fracture of the thyroid cartilage with mucosal tear. He is breathing comfortably via tracheostomy. What is the most appropriate surgical approach at this stage?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Surgical repair with open reduction, cartilage wiring, and mucosal repair within 3–5 days

 

This is the standard timing and protocol for operative repair: reduce cartilage fractures, repair mucosa, stabilize with wires or miniplates, and consider internal splinting if needed.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate open reduction and plating of thyroid cartilage fracture: Incorrect. Immediate repair may be complicated by edema; ideal timing is 3–5 days after injury once swelling reduces.

 

Option B. Endotracheal intubation followed by conservative management: Incorrect. Intubation is not preferred in laryngeal trauma due to risk of worsening injury. Tracheostomy is safer and already done here.

 

Option D. Observation only, as the tracheostomy is already done: Incorrect. Without definitive repair, long-term sequelae like stenosis or poor voice outcomes may occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Open surgical repair of laryngeal trauma is ideally done within 3–5 days and includes cartilage reduction, mucosal repair, and internal stenting when needed.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 288

questions.text: A 42-year-old male who suffered laryngotracheal trauma in a car accident 3 weeks ago now presents with increasing stridor, hoarseness, and effortful breathing. Flexible laryngoscopy reveals narrowing at the subglottic level. What is the most likely complication he has developed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laryngeal stenosis

 

Laryngeal stenosis—especially at the subglottic, glottic, or supraglottic level—is a common delayed complication following laryngotracheal trauma due to fibrosis, scarring, or poor healing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury: Incorrect. This would typically cause vocal cord paralysis, but not significant subglottic narrowing or stridor unless bilateral.

 

Option C. Arytenoid dislocation: Incorrect. This may cause hoarseness or voice changes, but not progressive stridor with subglottic narrowing.

 

Option D. Perichondritis of the thyroid cartilage: Incorrect. This would present with localized pain, swelling, and possible abscess but not isolated airway stenosis after 3 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal stenosis (supraglottic, glottic, or subglottic) is a common late complication of laryngotracheal trauma due to scarring and fibrosis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 288

choices.text: Strict voice rest and supportive care

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with sudden hoarseness, throat discomfort worsened by talking, and a dry cough that intensifies at night. He had symptoms of an upper respiratory tract infection for the past 2 days. On indirect laryngoscopy, erythema and edema of the aryepiglottic folds and ventricular bands are noted, while vocal cords appear normal. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strict voice rest and supportive care

 

Vocal rest, steam inhalation, and symptomatic relief are the mainstay of management in acute viral laryngitis, especially in early stages where vocal cords appear normal but surrounding structures are inflamed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate corticosteroids: Incorrect. Steroids are helpful in thermal or chemical laryngitis, but not routinely used in simple viral acute laryngitis unless airway edema is severe.

 

Option B. Emergency tracheostomy: Incorrect. This is indicated only in severe airway obstruction such as epiglottitis, not in typical acute laryngitis.

 

Option D. Broad-spectrum antibiotics and nebulized adrenaline: Incorrect. Antibiotics are reserved for secondary bacterial infections with fever and purulent sputum. Nebulized adrenaline is used in acute laryngeal obstruction, not routine laryngitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strict voice rest and symptomatic care are the cornerstone of management in uncomplicated acute laryngitis, especially of viral origin.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 289

choices.text: Perform indirect laryngoscopy to visualize the epiglottis
Order a throat swab and wait for culture results
Intubate in an operation theatre and start IV antibiotics
Prescribe oral antibiotics and send the child home

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the emergency room with high-grade fever, drooling, dysphagia, and inspiratory stridor. The symptoms began abruptly and have worsened rapidly. The child is sitting in a tripod position and appears anxious. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intubate in an operation theatre and start IV antibiotics

 

In a child with signs of impending airway obstruction (stridor, tripod posture, drooling), airway management is the priority. IV antibiotics like ampicillin or third-gen cephalosporins should be started immediately without waiting for culture.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Perform indirect laryngoscopy to visualize the epiglottis: Incorrect. This may precipitate complete airway obstruction in a child with acute epiglottitis. Visualization should only be done in an OT setup with intubation readiness.

 

Option B. Order a throat swab and wait for culture results: Incorrect. Do not delay antibiotics for cultures. Empirical treatment should be started immediately.

 

Option D. Prescribe oral antibiotics and send the child home: Incorrect. This condition is potentially life-threatening and needs hospitalization and IV therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute epiglottitis in children is a medical emergency; airway protection with intubation followed by IV antibiotics is the immediate priority.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 289

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a high-grade fever, drooling, and inspiratory stridor. The mother states that the symptoms started a few hours ago and have worsened quickly. On examination, the child is sitting leaning forward with an anxious look and prefers not to lie down. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute epiglottitis

 

This is classically characterized by rapid onset, high-grade fever, drooling, dysphagia, stridor, and tripod posture in children.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup): Incorrect. Croup has a gradual onset, barking cough, and affects the subglottic region. It is less likely to cause drooling or tripod positioning.

 

 

Option B. Acute tonsillitis: Incorrect. Though sore throat is common, stridor, drooling, and tripod posture are not typical of tonsillitis. Fever is also less severe than epiglottitis.

 

 

Option C. Foreign body aspiration: Incorrect. Usually presents with sudden onset of choking or coughing, and is more likely unilateral wheeze than biphasic stridor. Fever is uncommon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute epiglottitis in children presents with abrupt onset of high fever, dysphagia, drooling, and stridor; rapid progression may lead to airway obstruction.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 289

choices.text: Perform indirect laryngoscopy in the outpatient setting
Perform direct laryngoscopy under local anesthesia
Perform laryngoscopy in the operating room with intubation backup

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with acute onset of high fever, drooling, and inspiratory stridor. He is sitting in the tripod position. The physician suspects acute epiglottitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating the airway?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Perform laryngoscopy in the operating room with intubation backup

 

Examination of the airway, if necessary, must be done in the OR with facilities for intubation or tracheostomy, as sudden airway collapse can occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perform indirect laryngoscopy in the outpatient setting: Incorrect. This may precipitate complete airway obstruction and is contraindicated in suspected epiglottitis unless done in a controlled setting.

 

Option B. Perform direct laryngoscopy under local anesthesia: Incorrect. Like indirect laryngoscopy, this is risky in children with acute epiglottitis. Airway manipulation should only be done in a secured setting.

 

Option C. Order a lateral neck X-ray: Incorrect. While X-ray may show the classic thumb sign, it should not delay airway management in a child with stridor and respiratory distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected acute epiglottitis, airway examination should only be done in the operating room under controlled conditions to avoid precipitating complete obstruction.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 289

choices.text: Wait for blood and throat culture results before initiating antibiotics
Start parenteral ampicillin and observe in outpatient setting
Hospitalize the patient and initiate IV antibiotics and steroids
Perform immediate direct laryngoscopy in the emergency room

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with high-grade fever, sore throat, drooling, and inspiratory stridor. He is sitting in a tripod position and struggling to breathe. Acute epiglottitis is suspected. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hospitalize the patient and initiate IV antibiotics and steroids

 

Immediate hospitalization, IV antibiotics (e.g., ampicillin or a 3rd-generation cephalosporin), and steroids (hydrocortisone/dexamethasone) are recommended. Airway management should be closely monitored.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait for blood and throat culture results before initiating antibiotics: Incorrect. Treatment should not be delayed while awaiting cultures. This is a potentially life-threatening emergency.

 

Option B. Start parenteral ampicillin and observe in outpatient setting: Incorrect. Children with suspected acute epiglottitis must be hospitalized due to the risk of sudden airway obstruction.

 

Option D. Perform immediate direct laryngoscopy in the emergency room: Incorrect. Airway examination should only be done in a controlled setting like the operating room with intubation/tracheostomy backup due to risk of sudden airway collapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute epiglottitis requires immediate hospitalization with IV antibiotics and steroids; airway should be secured in a controlled setting if obstruction is suspected.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 289

choices.text: Swelling of the aryepiglottic folds and epiglottis
Inflammation and edema of the subglottic region with thick secretions
Formation of a pseudomembrane over the larynx due to diphtheria
Avulsion of arytenoid cartilage leading to acute airway collapse

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child is brought to the emergency department with a history of barking cough, hoarseness, low-grade fever, and inspiratory stridor. The condition began after a recent upper respiratory tract infection. Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathological mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inflammation and edema of the subglottic region with thick secretions

 

This is the hallmark of acute laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis (croup). The subglottic area’s loose areolar tissue becomes edematous, and tenacious secretions can occlude the airway.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Swelling of the aryepiglottic folds and epiglottis: Incorrect. This describes acute epiglottitis, not croup.

 

Option C. Formation of a pseudomembrane over the larynx due to diphtheria: Incorrect. This describes laryngeal diphtheria, a rare cause nowadays due to immunization.

 

Option D. Avulsion of arytenoid cartilage leading to acute airway collapse: Incorrect. This occurs in laryngeal trauma, not in typical viral croup.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis (croup) is caused by viral infection leading to subglottic edema and thick secretions, resulting in airway obstruction and stridor.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 290

questions.text: A 1.5-year-old boy presents with fever, hoarseness, and a barking cough for the past 2 days. On examination, he has a temperature of 39.5°C, inspiratory stridor, and suprasternal retractions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis (Croup)

 

Classic signs include barking cough, hoarseness, inspiratory stridor, low to moderate fever (~39–40°C), and signs of upper airway obstruction such as suprasternal retraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute epiglottitis: Incorrect. Although high-grade fever and stridor are seen, the classic presentation includes drooling, dysphagia, and tripod posture. Cough is usually absent.

 

Option B. Bronchiolitis: Incorrect. Presents with wheezing, not stridor. More likely to cause expiratory difficulty and lower respiratory signs.

 

Option C. Foreign body aspiration: Incorrect. Sudden onset of coughing or choking is typical; no preceding fever or gradual worsening. Inspiratory and/or expiratory stridor may occur depending on location of obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Croup typically presents in children with hoarseness, barking cough, fever, inspiratory stridor, and suprasternal retractions due to subglottic airway obstruction.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 290

choices.text: Administer humidified air, steroids, and racemic adrenaline

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child presents with a barking cough, hoarseness, stridor, and fever. He is diagnosed with acute laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer humidified air, steroids, and racemic adrenaline

 

This is the standard initial approach. Humidification loosens secretions, steroids reduce laryngeal oedema, and racemic adrenaline offers rapid relief of stridor by vasoconstriction of airway mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate tracheostomy: Incorrect. Tracheostomy is reserved for severe airway obstruction not responding to medical management, especially if intubation is needed >72 hours.

 

Option B. Start oral azithromycin and discharge: Incorrect. Croup often requires hospitalization due to risk of respiratory distress; azithromycin is not first-line, and discharge at this stage is unsafe.

 

Option D. Perform bronchoscopy to remove secretions: Incorrect. Not indicated in croup and may worsen symptoms. It is reserved for suspected foreign body or thick pseudomembrane obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initial treatment of croup includes humidified air, systemic steroids, and nebulized racemic adrenaline to relieve airway obstruction and inflammation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 291

choices.text: Vocal cord paralysis due to nerve injury
Sudden airway obstruction due to pseudomembrane

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with fever, hoarseness, and increasing respiratory distress. On examination, a greyish-white membrane is seen over the laryngeal inlet. What is the most likely complication if this condition is not treated promptly?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sudden airway obstruction due to pseudomembrane

 

In laryngeal diphtheria, a tough pseudomembrane forms over the larynx and trachea, which can completely block the airway, leading to stridor, respiratory distress, and death if not treated urgently.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal cord paralysis due to nerve injury: Though neurological complications can occur due to exotoxin, they are not immediate or as rapidly fatal as airway obstruction.

 

Option C. Recurrent upper respiratory tract infections: Not a typical feature or complication of diphtheria. This is more common in conditions like adenoid hypertrophy or sinusitis.

 

Option D. Bronchiectasis due to chronic inflammation: This is seen in chronic infections like tuberculosis or cystic fibrosis, not in acute diphtheritic laryngitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal diphtheria can lead to life-threatening airway obstruction due to pseudomembrane formation and systemic toxicity from exotoxins.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 290

choices.text: Sudden onset high-grade fever and toxic appearance
Thick white membrane on posterior pharyngeal wall that bleeds on removal
Muffled voice with drooling of saliva and tripod posture

questions.text: A 5-year-old unvaccinated child presents with hoarseness, croupy cough, inspiratory stridor, and low-grade fever. On examination, a greyish-white membrane is seen over the tonsils and pharynx, and attempting to remove it causes bleeding. Which of the following findings most strongly supports the diagnosis of laryngeal diphtheria?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thick white membrane on posterior pharyngeal wall that bleeds on removal

 

This is characteristic of diphtheria. The greyish-white pseudomembrane adheres tightly to mucosa and bleeds on removal. Combined with toxicity, stridor, and hoarseness, this is classical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sudden onset high-grade fever and toxic appearance: Seen in epiglottitis, which has a more rapid and acute course compared to insidious onset of diphtheria.

 

Option C. Inspiratory stridor without any fever: Suggests congenital causes or non-infective airway obstruction (e.g. laryngomalacia), not diphtheria.

 

Option D. Muffled voice with drooling of saliva and tripod posture: These are classic features of acute epiglottitis, not diphtheria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a bleeding greyish-white membrane over the pharynx with stridor and toxicity is diagnostic of laryngeal diphtheria.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 291

choices.text: Wait for culture confirmation before starting treatment
Administer diphtheria antitoxin after skin sensitivity testing
Perform direct laryngoscopy in the outpatient setting
Give steroids to reduce membrane-related inflammation

questions.text: A 6-year-old unvaccinated child presents with hoarseness, low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and a greyish-white membrane over the pharynx. Diphtheria is clinically suspected. Which of the following is most appropriate in the initial management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer diphtheria antitoxin after skin sensitivity testing

 

Treatment is started on clinical suspicion and not delayed for culture confirmation. Antitoxin neutralizes circulating diphtheria toxin and is the mainstay of treatment. A test dose is given before administration to check for hypersensitivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait for culture confirmation before starting treatment: Delay in treatment can lead to fatal complications such as airway obstruction or myocarditis. Culture confirms diagnosis, but treatment is started immediately based on clinical suspicion.

 

Option C. Perform direct laryngoscopy in the outpatient setting: Risky and can precipitate complete airway obstruction. If needed, should be done in OT setting under airway-secured conditions.

 

Option D. Give steroids to reduce membrane-related inflammation: Steroids are not routinely used in diphtheria and are not a substitute for antitoxin or antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of suspected laryngeal diphtheria should be initiated immediately with diphtheria antitoxin and antibiotics, without waiting for culture confirmation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 291

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of head and neck radiation therapy presents with progressive inspiratory stridor and hoarseness. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals oedema of the supraglottic region. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management if the patient shows signs of respiratory distress?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency tracheostomy

 

In cases of airway obstruction due to laryngeal oedema, securing the airway is the first priority. If there is severe obstruction or rapidly progressing stridor, tracheostomy or endotracheal intubation is immediately required to prevent respiratory arrest.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral steroids and nebulized bronchodilators: These may be helpful in mild or moderate cases of oedema (especially post-radiation or allergic causes) but are not adequate in the setting of respiratory distress.

 

Option C. Antihistamines and observation: Not appropriate in acute respiratory compromise. Antihistamines may be useful in mild allergic reactions, but airway must be secured first.

 

Option D. Adrenaline nebulization followed by antibiotics: While adrenaline (epinephrine) is effective in angioneurotic oedema, in patients with impending airway obstruction, surgical airway management takes precedence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal oedema with airway compromise requires immediate airway management—tracheostomy or intubation—to prevent life-threatening obstruction.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 291

choices.text: Voice rest, elimination of infection, and avoidance of irritants

questions.text: A 48-year-old coal mine worker presents with persistent hoarseness, frequent throat clearing, and dry cough for the past 6 months. He is a chronic smoker and gives a history of repeated upper respiratory infections. Laryngoscopy reveals bilateral dull red, rounded vocal cords with flecks of thick mucus. What is the most appropriate initial management strategy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Voice rest, elimination of infection, and avoidance of irritants

 

This is the mainstay of management in chronic hyperaemic laryngitis. Treatment focuses on removing precipitating factors such as smoking, infection in the sinuses/tonsils/teeth/chest, and occupational exposures. Voice therapy and steam inhalation help reduce symptoms and inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate microlaryngeal surgery: Not indicated in diffuse inflammatory conditions without mass lesions or nodules. Surgery is reserved for structural or neoplastic lesions.

 

Option B. Empirical antitubercular therapy: No evidence here supports TB as a diagnosis. ATD should never be started empirically without confirmation.

 

Option D. Oral corticosteroids and antibiotics: May help in acute laryngitis or secondary infection, but not a routine treatment in chronic hyperaemic laryngitis unless specific superadded infection is evident.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic hyperaemic laryngitis is managed conservatively by eliminating infections and irritants, with voice rest and supportive care.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 292

questions.text: A 45-year-old male chronic smoker and industrial worker presents with long-standing hoarseness, frequent throat clearing, and vocal fatigue. Laryngoscopic examination reveals dusky red, thickened, and nodular vocal cords with impaired mobility. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic hyperplastic laryngitis

 

 

This condition occurs due to prolonged irritation (smoking, vocal abuse, pollution) and presents with hoarseness, throat clearing, and vocal fatigue. Laryngoscopy shows thickened, dusky red, nodular cords with impaired mobility due to mucosal infiltration or joint stiffness. It is more common in males (8:1) in the 30–50 years age group.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal cord carcinoma: Carcinoma presents with progressive hoarseness and may show unilateral mass or ulceration. Bilateral symmetrical thickening favors a benign inflammatory cause.

 

 

Option C. Acute laryngitis: Presents with sudden onset hoarseness and typically shows erythema and edema but not nodular changes or impaired mobility seen in chronic hyperplastic forms.

 

 

Option D. Reinke’s edema: This is a localized form of chronic laryngitis with gelatinous swelling in Reinke’s space and is more commonly bilateral and symmetrical, but typically causes fusiform swelling of cords—not the nodular appearance described here.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic hyperplastic laryngitis presents with hoarseness, thickened and nodular cords, and impaired mobility, especially in male smokers exposed to irritants.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 292

choices.text: Use of ventricular bands for phonation

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, a retired drama teacher and chronic smoker, presents with hoarseness and a low-pitched, rough voice for several months. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals bilateral pale fusiform swellings of the vocal cords with overhanging ventricular bands. Which of the following best explains his altered voice?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Use of ventricular bands for phonation

 

In Reinke’s edema, the true cords are edematous and cannot vibrate efficiently. Patients compensate by using false cords (ventricular bands) for phonation, resulting in a rough, low-pitched voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased subglottic pressure: While it may affect voice dynamics, it is not the primary cause of the hoarseness in Reinke’s edema.

 

Option C. Hyperadduction of vocal cords: Seen in functional voice disorders, not typical of Reinke’s edema.

 

Option D. Vocal cord paralysis: Leads to breathy or weak voice, not low-pitched hoarseness with fusiform swelling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Reinke’s edema, patients develop hoarseness due to use of ventricular bands for phonation, as the edematous vocal cords cannot vibrate effectively.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 292

choices.text: Speech therapy and anti-reflux medication only
Total laryngectomy due to suspicion of malignancy

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, chronic smoker and heavy alcohol consumer, complains of persistent hoarseness and throat irritation. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals symmetrical, greyish granular thickening in the interarytenoid region and posterior vocal cords. What is the next best step in the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Microlaryngoscopic biopsy of the lesion

 

Although pachydermia laryngis is benign and does not undergo malignant transformation, biopsy is essential to rule out carcinoma or tuberculosis because of the similar clinical appearance.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Empirical antibiotic therapy: Not indicated unless there is an associated infection; does not address the diagnosis.

 

Option B. Speech therapy and anti-reflux medication only: These are part of the long-term treatment, but biopsy is necessary first to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Option D. Total laryngectomy due to suspicion of malignancy: Too aggressive; definitive diagnosis must be established before considering such radical surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pachydermia laryngis presents with symmetrical thickening in the interarytenoid area; biopsy is mandatory to rule out carcinoma or tuberculosis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 293

choices.text: Humidification, glucose–glycerine sprays, and treatment of associated nasal/pharyngeal conditions

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with persistent hoarseness of voice and dry, irritating cough. She reports temporary improvement after coughing out crusts. On laryngoscopic examination, atrophic laryngeal mucosa covered with foul-smelling crusts is noted. What is the most appropriate management approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Humidification, glucose–glycerine sprays, and treatment of associated nasal/pharyngeal conditions

 

This is the mainstay of management in atrophic laryngitis (laryngitis sicca). It aims to loosen crusts, provide mucosal hydration, and address any associated atrophic rhinitis or pharyngitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral corticosteroids and voice therapy: Steroids are not useful in atrophic laryngitis and may worsen mucosal dryness.

 

Option B. Broad-spectrum antibiotics: There is no evidence of infection; this is a chronic atrophic condition, not a bacterial one.

 

Option D. Microlaryngoscopic excision of mucosal crusts: Not typically required; crusts loosen with humidification and sprays. Surgical excision is unnecessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic laryngitis is treated with humidification, glucose–glycerine or pine oil sprays, expectorants, and management of associated atrophic rhinitis or pharyngitis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 293

choices.text: Bilateral vocal cord paralysis with bowing
Shiny white pseudomembranes over vocal cords
Mouse-nibbled ulceration of the vocal cords
Sessile polypoidal mass over anterior commissure

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of pulmonary tuberculosis presents with hoarseness of voice, odynophagia, and referred otalgia. On laryngeal examination, mamillated swelling is seen in the interarytenoid region and superficial ragged ulceration is noted over the arytenoids. Which of the following findings is most characteristic of laryngeal tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mouse-nibbled ulceration of the vocal cords

 

  • This is a classic laryngoscopic finding in TB larynx due to superficial ulceration of the cords.
  • TB ulceration typically presents as irregular, shallow ulcers with granulation tissue, especially over the posterior larynx.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral vocal cord paralysis with bowing: This is more characteristic of neurological causes or malignancy, not TB.

 

Option B. Shiny white pseudomembranes over vocal cords: Seen in diphtheria, not TB.

 

Option D. Sessile polypoidal mass over anterior commissure: More typical of vocal cord polyps or carcinoma, not tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulceration with a "mouse-nibbled" appearance of the vocal cords is a classic laryngoscopic finding in laryngeal tuberculosis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 293

questions.text: A 48-year-old male, chronic smoker, presents with hoarseness, odynophagia, and ear pain for 2 months. Laryngoscopy reveals ulcerative lesions over the posterior vocal cords and arytenoids. He also has a known history of pulmonary tuberculosis. What is the next best step in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Biopsy of the laryngeal lesion

 

Though TB is suspected due to history and clinical picture, biopsy is essential to rule out malignancy, especially in chronic smokers and to differentiate from carcinoma or other ulcerative lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT scan of neck: Helpful for anatomical assessment, but not diagnostic or confirmatory.

 

Option B. Sputum culture for Mycobacterium tuberculosis: May support pulmonary TB but does not confirm laryngeal involvement.

 

Option D. Therapeutic trial of corticosteroids: This is contraindicated without diagnosis; may worsen TB or mask malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biopsy of the laryngeal lesion is essential to confirm tuberculosis and exclude carcinoma in suspected laryngeal TB.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 293

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with known lupus vulgaris of the nose and pharynx is found to have asymptomatic destruction of the epiglottis on laryngoscopy. She has no history of pulmonary tuberculosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lupus of the larynx

 

It is a painless, indolent tubercular condition, often associated with lupus of nose and pharynx. It commonly affects the anterior larynx, especially the epiglottis, which may be completely destroyed. Patients often have no pulmonary TB.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngeal carcinoma: Carcinoma usually presents with pain, hoarseness, and is not characteristically associated with lupus of the nose.

 

Option B. Laryngeal tuberculosis: In contrast to lupus, laryngeal TB typically affects the posterior larynx and is often symptomatic, with hoarseness and pain.

 

Option D. Chronic laryngitis: This would cause hoarseness, cough, and does not cause destruction of epiglottis or occur silently.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lupus of the larynx is an indolent, asymptomatic tubercular infection affecting the anterior larynx, especially the epiglottis, and is managed with anti-tubercular therapy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 294

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with progressive hoarseness and a smooth laryngeal swelling that has started to ulcerate. He has no history of trauma or malignancy. Serological tests for infections are advised. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tertiary syphilis of the larynx

 

A rare condition today, but when present, gumma of the tertiary stage may appear as a smooth swelling in any part of the larynx, later leading to ulceration. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy and serological tests (e.g., VDRL, FTA-ABS). Laryngeal stenosis is a known complication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngeal carcinoma: Usually presents as irregular, ulcerative or exophytic mass, with more aggressive local features, and not confirmed by serology.

 

Option B. Tuberculosis of the larynx: More commonly affects the posterior larynx and presents with ulceration, pain, hoarseness, and associated pulmonary TB findings.

 

Option D. Contact ulcer: Occurs over the vocal processes due to vocal trauma or GERD, not associated with ulcerating masses or serological positivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tertiary syphilis of the larynx presents as a smooth swelling that may ulcerate, diagnosed by biopsy and serological tests, and may lead to laryngeal stenosis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 294

questions.text: A patient with known lepromatous leprosy presents with hoarseness and dysphagia. On laryngoscopic examination, there is diffuse nodular infiltration of the epiglottis and aryepiglottic folds. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leprosy of the larynx

 

Rare condition, usually associated with cutaneous and nasal leprosy. Presents with diffuse nodular infiltration of epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and arytenoids. Lesions may ulcerate. Biopsy confirms diagnosis. Healing may result in laryngeal inlet deformity and stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculosis of the larynx: Involves posterior larynx, more ulcerative, with mammillated interarytenoid swelling and association with pulmonary TB.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis of the larynx: Involves supraglottic structures, but presents with non-caseating granulomas and systemic features (e.g., lung, eye involvement).

 

Option D. Chronic hypertrophic laryngitis: Features symmetrical thickening and hyperplasia, not nodular infiltration or association with cutaneous/systemic disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leprosy of the larynx presents with nodular infiltration of supraglottic structures and is diagnosed by biopsy; healing can cause deformity and stenosis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 294

choices.text: Surgical excision of lesion as first-line

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient from a rural area presents with hoarseness, wheezing, and nasal obstruction. Examination reveals a red, smooth subglottic swelling. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis infection. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tetracycline or streptomycin with steroids

 

This is the treatment of choice for laryngeal scleroma. Antibiotics target the Klebsiella species, while steroids help reduce fibrosis and prevent stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High-dose corticosteroids alone: Steroids are adjunctive to antibiotics in scleroma; alone, they are insufficient and will not eradicate the infection.

 

Option B. Antitubercular therapy: The causative agent is Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, not Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Surgical excision of lesion as first-line: Surgery is reserved for complications like subglottic stenosis, not the first line of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scleroma of the larynx, caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, is treated with tetracycline or streptomycin and adjunctive steroids to prevent fibrosis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 295

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male on long-term inhaled corticosteroids presents with hoarseness and odynophagia. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals whitish patches over the vocal cords. A biopsy confirms fungal infiltration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laryngeal candidiasis

 

Candidiasis is the most common laryngeal mycosis, often seen in immunocompromised or steroid-inhaling patients. Presents as white patches and requires biopsy for confirmation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngeal tuberculosis: TB commonly affects posterior larynx with ulceration and caseation, not white plaques.

 

 

Option B. Laryngeal carcinoma: Presents as irregular growths or ulceroproliferative lesions, not white plaques.

 

 

Option D. Contact ulcer: Usually located at the posterior third of vocal cords due to mechanical trauma, not fungal in origin.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal mycosis, especially candidiasis, should be suspected in immunocompromised patients with hoarseness and white laryngeal patches, confirmed by biopsy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 295

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with noisy breathing since birth. The stridor is inspiratory, worsens with crying, but improves when placed in the prone position. The baby has a normal cry and is feeding well. Flexible laryngoscopy shows an omega-shaped epiglottis and floppy aryepiglottic folds. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laryngomalacia

 

Most common congenital laryngeal anomaly. Presents with inspiratory stridor, worsens on crying, improves in prone position. Flexible laryngoscopy confirms omega-shaped epiglottis and floppy supraglottic structures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal cord paralysis: Typically associated with weak cry and possibly aspiration. Laryngomalacia has normal cry.

 

Option B. Subglottic stenosis: Causes biphasic stridor, not positional or relieved by prone position.

 

 

Option D. Laryngeal web: Usually presents with hoarseness or weak cry; not positional or with normal cry.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngomalacia presents with inspiratory stridor in neonates that improves in prone position and shows floppy supraglottic structures on laryngoscopy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 295

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant with a history of recurrent stridor is brought in by the parents. The baby has a normal cry and becomes breathless during episodes of upper respiratory tract infections. Endoscopy reveals narrowing of the airway just below the vocal cords, with a subglottic diameter of 3.8 mm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Congenital subglottic stenosis

 

Caused by thickened cricoid cartilage or fibrous tissue just below the vocal cords. Presents with normal cry and intermittent stridor worsened by infections. A subglottic diameter <4 mm in a term infant confirms the diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngomalacia: Although it presents with stridor, it involves the supraglottic structures and is diagnosed by omega-shaped epiglottis and floppy aryepiglottic folds. The obstruction is not below the vocal cords.

 

 

Option B. Vocal cord paralysis: Usually associated with weak cry and vocal cord immobility, not with isolated subglottic narrowing.

 

Option D. Laryngeal web: Typically causes weak cry or hoarseness and is located at the glottic level, not subglottic.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital subglottic stenosis presents with intermittent stridor and normal cry, diagnosed by subglottic diameter <4 mm in full-term neonates (<3mm in pre-term).

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 295

questions.text: A newborn presents with respiratory distress and a weak cry since birth. On endoscopic evaluation, a thin membrane with a concave posterior margin is seen between the vocal cords. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laryngeal web

 

Caused by incomplete recanalization of the larynx. Membrane is typically between the vocal cords with a concave posterior margin. Presents with airway obstruction, aphonia, or weak cry from birth.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngomalacia: Presents with inspiratory stridor and normal cry. It involves supraglottic structures, not between vocal cords.

 

 

Option B. Congenital subglottic stenosis: The obstruction is below the vocal cords. Cry is usually normal unless complicated.

 

 

Option D. Bilateral vocal cord paralysis: Can cause airway obstruction and weak cry, but cords will appear immobile, not joined by a membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal web presents at birth with weak cry and airway obstruction due to a thin membrane between the vocal cords, often with a concave posterior margin.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 295

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with progressive stridor over the last few weeks. Cry is normal. Examination reveals cutaneous haemangiomas and direct laryngoscopy shows a reddish-blue mass below the vocal cords. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Subglottic haemangioma

 

Presents between 3–6 months of age with normal cry, progressive stridor, and a reddish-blue subglottic mass. Associated with cutaneous haemangiomas in ~50% of cases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngomalacia: Presents from birth or shortly after with inspiratory stridor that improves in prone position. No mass is seen below the vocal cords.

 

 

Option B. Laryngeal web: Typically diagnosed at birth with weak cry or aphonia and membrane between vocal cords, not a vascular mass.

 

 

Option D. Congenital subglottic stenosis: Present at birth or early infancy. Cry is normal, but no vascular mass is seen. Narrowed airway confirmed by endoscopy or CT.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subglottic haemangioma presents at 3–6 months with normal cry, progressive stridor, and reddish-blue mass below vocal cords often associated with skin haemangiomas.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 295

questions.text: A neonate presents with recurrent aspiration pneumonia and coughing, choking, and cyanosis during feeds. What is the most likely congenital anomaly responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laryngo-oesophageal cleft

 

A congenital defect due to failure of cricoid lamina fusion, leading to direct communication between larynx and esophagus — causing aspiration, choking, cyanosis during feeds, and recurrent pneumonitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheoesophageal fistula: Presents with similar feeding-related symptoms but is typically associated with esophageal atresia and inability to pass a nasogastric tube.

 

 

Option B. Laryngomalacia: Presents with inspiratory stridor, worsens on crying, improves in prone position; does not cause aspiration or cyanosis during feeds.

 

 

Option C. Subglottic stenosis: Causes stridor and respiratory distress, especially during upper respiratory infections, but not choking or aspiration during feeds.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngo-oesophageal cleft presents with choking, cyanosis, and aspiration pneumonia during feeds due to communication between the larynx and esophagus.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 295

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with inspiratory stridor and respiratory distress. On flexible laryngoscopy, a bluish, fluid-filled swelling is seen in the aryepiglottic fold. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laryngeal cyst

 

A bluish, fluid-filled smooth supraglottic swelling, typically in the aryepiglottic fold, may cause respiratory obstruction. May need needle aspiration or tracheostomy acutely; definitive treatment is deroofing or CO₂ laser excision.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngomalacia: Most common congenital cause of stridor. Due to floppy supraglottic structures, worsens on crying, improves in prone position. No discrete cystic swelling is seen.

 

 

Option C. Subglottic hemangioma: Presents later (3–6 months age), usually with normal cry and progressive stridor. Seen as a reddish-blue mass below the vocal cords.

 

 

Option D. Epiglottitis: Acute onset with high fever, drooling, and toxic appearance. Indirect visualization avoided due to risk of complete obstruction. Swollen, cherry-red epiglottis may be seen.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal cyst presents as a bluish supraglottic swelling in the aryepiglottic fold and may cause airway obstruction, requiring deroofing or CO₂ laser excision.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 295

questions.text: A 10-month-old child presents with persistent noisy breathing that occurs during both inspiration and expiration. On flexible laryngoscopy, bilateral vocal cord nodularity is noted. What type of stridor is most likely in this child, and what is the probable site of obstruction?
questions.solution:
Ans C) Biphasic stridor – glottis

 

Biphasic stridor occurs when both inspiration and expiration are affected, suggesting glottic, subglottic, or cervical tracheal lesions like laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, or subglottic stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inspiratory stridor – supraglottis: Seen in supraglottic obstructions like laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess. Occurs only during inspiration.

 

Option B. Expiratory stridor – bronchi: Seen in bronchial obstructions such as foreign body or bronchomalacia. Heard only during expiration.

 

Option D. Biphasic stridor – thoracic trachea: Lesions of thoracic trachea typically cause expiratory stridor, not biphasic.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biphasic stridor is characteristic of glottic, subglottic, or cervical tracheal obstructions such as vocal cord paralysis or laryngeal papillomas.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 296

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with inspiratory stridor that worsens when crying and improves in prone position. On flexible laryngoscopy, the epiglottis is curled and omega-shaped, with floppy aryepiglottic folds. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laryngomalacia

 

  • Most common congenital cause of inspiratory stridor in infants.
  • Stridor worsens on crying, improves when prone.
  • Flexible laryngoscopy: omega-shaped epiglottis, floppy supraglottic structures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subglottic stenosis: Presents with biphasic stridor, especially after upper respiratory infections. Cry is normal. No floppiness of supraglottic structures.

 

 

Option C. Vocal cord paralysis: Usually presents with biphasic stridor, weak cry, and possibly aspiration.

 

Option D. Laryngeal web: Causes weak cry or aphonia since birth with airway obstruction, but does not improve with positioning and has different laryngoscopic findings.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of congenital inspiratory stridor in infants, characterized by floppy supraglottic structures and an omega-shaped epiglottis, with symptoms worsening on crying and improving when prone.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 296

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents with intermittent inspiratory stridor since birth, which worsens during crying and feeding. The cry is normal, and there are no signs of acute infection. The parents deny any history of foreign body aspiration or trauma. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laryngomalacia

 

Most common congenital cause of stridor.

 

  • Starts at or soon after birth
  • Worsens with crying and feeding
  • Normal cry is characteristic
  • Improves in prone position
  • Fits the mode (gradual), duration (long), and timing of onset (congenital)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foreign body aspiration: Sudden onset is typical. Not likely here as symptoms are present since birth and are progressive, not acute. No history of aspiration.

 

Option C. Subglottic haemangioma: Typically presents around 3–6 months, not right from birth. Cry remains normal, but stridor is progressive and worsens over weeks/months. Less likely in this case due to age of onset.

 

 

Option D. Laryngeal cleft: Presents with aspiration during feeding and frequent cyanotic spells. History would indicate feeding difficulties and recurrent pneumonitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stridor present since birth, which worsens with crying and feeding but improves in prone position with a normal cry, is most suggestive of laryngomalacia.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 296

choices.text: Bilateral immobile vocal cords in abducted position

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with inspiratory stridor since birth, which decreases in prone position. On examination, the cry is normal, and no fever is noted. Flexible fibreoptic laryngoscopy is planned to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following findings on laryngoscopy is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Floppy epiglottis curled upon itself

 

Classic finding in laryngomalacia, the most common congenital cause of stridor.

 

  • Stridor since birth
  • Improves in prone position
  • Normal cry
  • Seen on flexible fibreoptic laryngoscopy as an omega (Ω)-shaped epiglottis, floppy aryepiglottic folds, and prominent arytenoids.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Greyish-white membrane over vocal cords: Suggestive of diphtheritic laryngitis, typically presents with fever, muffled voice, and toxic appearance. Not consistent with the history or afebrile status in this case.

 

Option C. Subglottic haemangioma: Usually presents later (3–6 months) with progressive stridor and normal cry, not from birth. Not the best match here.

 

 

Option D. Bilateral immobile vocal cords in abducted position: Seen in congenital vocal cord paralysis, which often causes a weak or absent cry and aspiration symptoms. This child has a normal cry, making this less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flexible fibreoptic laryngoscopy is the investigation of choice for evaluating infantile stridor and reveals an omega-shaped floppy epiglottis in laryngomalacia.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 297

choices.text: Chest X-ray in inspiratory and expiratory phases

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with biphasic stridor. Flexible laryngoscopy shows normal supraglottis and glottis. No foreign body is visualized. Chest X-ray is inconclusive. A vascular anomaly is suspected as the cause of airway compression. Which of the following is the most appropriate next investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CT scan with contrast

 

Best non-invasive test to evaluate mediastinal masses or vascular anomalies such as double aortic arch, anomalous pulmonary artery, or vascular rings causing tracheal compression. These are common causes of biphasic stridor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct laryngoscopy with microlaryngoscopy: Useful for evaluating laryngeal lesions, collecting secretions, and removing foreign bodies. However, not first-line for evaluating vascular anomalies compressing the trachea.

 

Option C. Barium swallow (oesophagogram): Helpful in tracheoesophageal fistula or oesophageal atresia, or to detect extrinsic tracheal compression by aberrant vessels. Used after CT scan if required.

 

Option D. Chest X-ray in inspiratory and expiratory phases: Good for radiolucent foreign bodies, but not ideal to assess vascular compressions or mediastinal pathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT scan with contrast is the investigation of choice for identifying vascular anomalies causing stridor due to tracheal compression.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 297

choices.text: Perform direct laryngoscopy in the emergency room
Arrange for airway management and perform laryngoscopy in the operating room

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of high fever, drooling of saliva, and inspiratory stridor. The child is sitting in a tripod position and looks toxic. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arrange for airway management and perform laryngoscopy in the operating room

 

This child likely has acute epiglottitis, a life-threatening condition requiring immediate airway protection. Laryngoscopy should be performed under general anesthesia in a setting where emergency intubation or tracheostomy can be performed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Order a lateral neck X-ray: Incorrect. Radiographs can precipitate complete airway obstruction due to stress or movement. Imaging should be avoided unless the airway is secured.

 

Option B. Start oral steroids and discharge: Incorrect. This is more appropriate for mild croup. The child in this case is toxic with acute airway compromise—typical of acute epiglottitis.

 

Option C. Perform direct laryngoscopy in the emergency room: Incorrect. It is risky and may lead to complete airway obstruction. Laryngoscopy should only be done in a controlled environment like the OR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child with suspected acute epiglottitis, airway management and laryngoscopy should be done in the operation theatre to avoid sudden airway obstruction.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 290

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with progressive hoarseness of voice and occasional throat discomfort. On indirect laryngoscopy, a smooth, round swelling is noted in the false vocal cord region. It does not move with respiration or phonation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ductal (retention) cyst

 

Ductal cysts arise from obstruction of the ducts of seromucinous glands of the laryngeal mucosa. Common sites include vallecula, aryepiglottic fold, false cords, and ventricles. These appear as smooth, non-mobile swellings and may cause hoarseness, cough, or dyspnoea if large.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal polyp: Incorrect. A vocal polyp is usually unilateral, pedunculated, and arises from the true vocal cord, typically caused by vocal abuse or trauma. It may move with phonation.

 

 

Option C. Reinke’s edema: Incorrect. Reinke’s edema involves bilateral, diffuse, gelatinous swelling of true vocal cords, primarily due to smoking or vocal abuse. It is not a localized cystic lesion.

 

 

Option D. Laryngeal granuloma: Incorrect. Granulomas usually occur at the vocal processes of arytenoids (posterior larynx) and are often related to intubation trauma or reflux. They appear more inflamed and irregular than smooth cysts.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ductal cysts of the larynx are retention cysts of seromucinous glands, commonly found in the false cords or vallecula, and may present with hoarseness or throat discomfort if large.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 305

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with hoarseness and a sensation of fullness in the throat. On laryngoscopic examination, a smooth cystic swelling is seen in the anterior part of the laryngeal ventricle obscuring part of the vocal cord. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Saccular cyst

 

Saccular cysts arise due to obstruction of the orifice of the laryngeal saccule, causing retention of secretions.

 

  • Anterior saccular cysts present in the anterior ventricle, obscuring the vocal cords.
  • Lateral saccular cysts are larger and may extend into the false cord, aryepiglottic fold, or even neck through the thyrohyoid membrane, mimicking a laryngocele.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ductal cyst: Incorrect. These are retention cysts of seromucinous glands, commonly located in vallecula, false cords, and ventricles, but do not typically originate from the laryngeal saccule or cause significant extension into false cords or neck.

 

 

Option C. Vocal polyp: Incorrect. Vocal polyps are soft, unilateral, often pedunculated, and arise from the true vocal cord, typically after vocal trauma. They don’t arise from the laryngeal saccule or extend laterally.

 

 

Option D. Laryngocele: Incorrect. A laryngocele is an air-filled dilation of the saccule, which may present externally through the thyrohyoid membrane, but it communicates with the laryngeal lumen and typically presents with cough-induced swelling. A saccular cyst is fluid-filled and does not communicate with the airway.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Saccular cysts arise from retention of secretions in the laryngeal saccule; anterior cysts obscure vocal cords while lateral ones may extend into false cords or neck.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 304

CO₂ laser excision is the preferred treatment
It rarely recurs after a single excision

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with progressive hoarseness, intermittent stridor, and difficulty breathing. Flexible fibreoptic laryngoscopy reveals multiple wart-like lesions in the supraglottic and glottic regions. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CO₂ laser excision is the preferred treatment

 

Microlaryngoscopy with CO₂ laser excision is the treatment of choice. It allows precise removal of lesions while preserving the underlying vocal ligament and minimizing trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HPV types 16 and 18: Incorrect. Juvenile respiratory papillomatosis is caused by HPV types 6 and 11, not 16 and 18 (which are high-risk oncogenic types associated with malignancies).

 

Option B. Frequent malignant transformation: Incorrect. Malignant transformation is rare in juvenile papillomatosis. The major issue is frequent recurrence and potential spread to the trachea and bronchi, especially in patients who have undergone tracheostomy.

 

Option D. Rarely recurs after single excision: Incorrect. The hallmark of juvenile papillomatosis is frequent recurrence, necessitating multiple surgeries over time. Adjuvants like interferon alpha-2a or 13-cis-retinoic acid are sometimes used, but have notable side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile respiratory papillomatosis, caused by HPV types 6 and 11, presents with hoarseness and stridor and is best treated by CO₂ laser excision due to its recurrent nature.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 305
