questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with mild hoarseness for the past few months. On flexible laryngoscopy, a single small papillomatous lesion is visualized arising from the anterior vocal cord. Histopathology confirms it to be a laryngeal papilloma. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is less aggressive and does not usually recur after excision

 

Adult-onset laryngeal papillomas are less aggressive, often solitary, and typically do not recur after microlaryngoscopic excision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. More common in females and shows high recurrence: Incorrect. Adult-onset papillomas are more common in males (2:1), and unlike juvenile papillomatosis, they are typically solitary and non-recurrent after surgical removal.

 

Option B. Multiple sites and tracheal spread: Incorrect. This is typical of juvenile papillomatosis, not adult-onset. Adult papillomas are usually localized to the anterior vocal cord or anterior commissure.

 

Option D. Treatment involves total laryngectomy: Incorrect. There is no need for total laryngectomy in adult-onset papillomas as they are benign and managed conservatively by surgical excision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adult-onset laryngeal papilloma is typically solitary, less aggressive, more common in males, and rarely recurs after surgical excision.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 305

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with progressive dyspnoea and a sensation of a lump in the throat for several months. Flexible laryngoscopy shows a submucosal bulge in the subglottic region. CT scan reveals a well-defined mass arising from the posterior plate of the cricoid cartilage. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laryngeal chondroma

 

Chondromas are benign cartilaginous tumors that most commonly arise from the cricoid cartilage, particularly its posterior plate. They may extend into the subglottic airway (causing dyspnoea) or grow posteriorly causing a lump in throat or dysphagia. CT is helpful for defining extent; CO₂ laser may assist in biopsy, and large/recurrent tumors may require laryngectomy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngeal carcinoma: Incorrect. Carcinomas of the larynx usually arise from the glottis or supraglottis and present with hoarseness as the primary symptom, not a sensation of lump or dysphagia from a posterior cricoid mass.

 

 

Option B. Vocal cord polyp: Incorrect. Polyps arise from the membranous vocal cord, are pedunculated and soft, and usually present with hoarseness, not subglottic obstruction or posterior mass effects.

 

 

Option D. Laryngeal papilloma: Incorrect. Papillomas are epithelial viral lesions (HPV-related), usually occur on the vocal cords or supraglottis, and are exophytic, not cartilaginous or submucosal masses arising from cartilage.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal chondromas typically arise from the cricoid cartilage, present as subglottic or posterior pharyngeal masses, and may require laryngofissure, pharyngotomy, or laryngectomy depending on size and recurrence.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 306

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with progressive inspiratory stridor. Flexible laryngoscopy reveals a vascular-looking lesion in the subglottic region. The parents mention a similar reddish lesion on the forehead. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subglottic haemangioma

 

Infantile haemangiomas commonly present within the first 6 months of life with stridor due to subglottic involvement. Around 50% of cases have associated haemangiomas in the head and neck region. They are mostly capillary type and may involute spontaneously, though severe cases may require tracheostomy or CO₂ laser vaporization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subglottic stenosis: Incorrect. Though it can present with stridor, it is usually secondary to prolonged intubation or congenital narrowing and lacks the vascular appearance or associated cutaneous haemangiomas.

 

 

Option C. Laryngeal papillomatosis: Incorrect. This is caused by HPV type 6/11 and typically presents with hoarseness or recurrent respiratory obstruction. The lesions are papillomatous, not vascular.

 

 

Option D. Laryngomalacia: Incorrect. It is the most common cause of stridor in infants but involves supraglottic collapse on inspiration, not vascular lesions or subglottic narrowing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infantile subglottic haemangiomas present in the first 6 months of life with stridor and may be associated with cutaneous haemangiomas; they are capillary type and can be treated with CO₂ laser if symptomatic.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 306

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with mild hoarseness for 3 months. Flexible laryngoscopy reveals a small submucosal nodule on the vocal cord. Biopsy shows large polygonal cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, and the overlying epithelium shows pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Granular cell tumour

 

This benign tumour arises from Schwann cells and is often submucosal. It shows pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia of the overlying mucosa, which may resemble carcinoma on histology. Treatment is microsurgical excision, and recurrence can occur if incompletely removed.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Incorrect. While pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia may resemble carcinoma on histology, granular cell tumour is benign and can mimic it. True carcinoma shows dysplasia or invasive features absent here.

 

 

Option B. Laryngeal papilloma: Incorrect. Papillomas are exophytic, warty growths caused by HPV and are usually not submucosal or associated with pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia.

 

 

Option D. Vocal cord cyst: Incorrect. These are fluid-filled lesions, not cellular tumours. They do not show pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia or arise from Schwann cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granular cell tumours of the larynx are benign Schwann cell neoplasms that can mimic carcinoma due to overlying pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia and require complete excision to prevent recurrence.

 

P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 306

choices.text: Tobacco and alcohol independently increase cancer risk, but together they have no additive effect.
Laryngeal carcinoma is equally prevalent among males and females in India.
Exposure to cigarette smoke and alcohol consumption increases risk up to 15-fold compared to each alone.
Radiation to the neck for benign conditions decreases the future risk of laryngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male chronic smoker and alcoholic presents with persistent hoarseness for 2 months. On laryngoscopy, a suspicious lesion is noted over the vocal cord. Which of the following statements regarding the epidemiology or etiology of laryngeal carcinoma is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exposure to cigarette smoke and alcohol consumption increases risk up to 15-fold compared to each alone.

 

The synergistic carcinogenic effect of tobacco (due to hydrocarbons like benzopyrene) and alcohol has been well documented. This combination significantly elevates cancer risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tobacco and alcohol independently increase cancer risk, but together they have no additive effect: Incorrect. This is factually wrong. The combined effect of tobacco and alcohol is synergistic, increasing the risk up to 15 times, whereas each individually increases it only 2–3 times.

 

Option B. Laryngeal carcinoma is equally prevalent among males and females in India: Incorrect. The disease is 10 times more common in males (4.79%) than in females (0.47%) in India, per National Cancer Registry (ICMR, 2005).

 

Option D. Radiation to the neck for benign conditions decreases the future risk of laryngeal carcinoma: Incorrect. On the contrary, previous neck radiation, even for benign lesions or laryngeal papilloma, increases the risk of malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Combined exposure to tobacco and alcohol significantly increases the risk of laryngeal carcinoma up to 15 times compared to either factor alone.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 307

questions.text: A 62-year-old chronic smoker presents with hoarseness of voice for 3 months. On laryngoscopy, a suspicious exophytic lesion is seen over the right true vocal cord. A biopsy is taken. Which of the following is the most likely histopathological diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Squamous cell carcinoma

 

This is the most common histologic type, accounting for 90–95% of laryngeal cancers. Cordal lesions tend to be well-differentiated, while supraglottic lesions are often anaplastic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoid cystic carcinoma: Incorrect. This is a malignant salivary gland tumour, seen rarely in the larynx. It represents a small proportion of non-squamous malignancies.

 

Option C. Chondrosarcoma: Incorrect. This is a rare sarcoma of the larynx, usually involving the cricoid cartilage. Not the typical pathology of cordal cancer.

 

Option D. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: Incorrect. Another salivary gland-type tumour, but it comprises a minor percentage of laryngeal malignancies (within the 5–10% non-SCC group).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Around 90–95% of laryngeal malignancies are squamous cell carcinomas; cordal lesions are typically well-differentiated, while supraglottic lesions may be anaplastic.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 307

questions.text: A 58-year-old male chronic smoker presents with hoarseness, mild dysphagia, and a foreign body sensation in the throat. Laryngoscopy reveals a lesion involving the medial wall of the left pyriform sinus and base of tongue mucosa, with normal vocal cord mobility. CT scan shows no cartilage invasion. What is the most appropriate T stage of this supraglottic laryngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T2

 

  • T2 includes tumors that invade more than one adjacent subsite of the supraglottis or glottis or regions outside supraglottis (like base of tongue, vallecula, pyriform sinus) but without fixation of vocal cords.
  • This patient has multiple subsites involved but no vocal cord fixation or deep invasion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T1: Incorrect. 

 

  • T1 is when the tumor is limited to only one subsite of the supraglottis and vocal cords are mobile.
  • Here, multiple adjacent subsites (pyriform sinus + base of tongue) are involved, so it’s not T1.

 

Option C. T3: Incorrect. 

 

  • T3 indicates either vocal cord fixation or invasion of deep structures like postcricoid area, pre-epiglottic space, paraglottic space, or minor thyroid cartilage invasion.
  • This case has no vocal cord fixation or deep tissue involvement.

 

Option D. T4a: Incorrect. 

 

  • T4a includes invasion through thyroid cartilage or into tissues beyond the larynx (like strap muscles, trachea, thyroid, etc.).
  • Again, none of these are present in this case.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

T2 supraglottic laryngeal cancer involves more than one adjacent subsite (e.g., base of tongue, vallecula, pyriform sinus) but without vocal cord fixation or deep invasion.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 308

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with history of heavy smoking presents with progressive hoarseness over 3 months. Flexible laryngoscopy reveals a tumor involving both true vocal cords, sparing supraglottic and subglottic regions. Vocal cord mobility is preserved. CT scan shows no cartilage erosion or spread beyond the glottis. What is the most appropriate T-stage?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T1b

 

  • T1b is defined as tumor involving both vocal cords, with normal vocal cord mobility and no extension to supraglottis or subglottis. This exactly fits the case described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T1a: Incorrect. T1a is when only one vocal cord is involved, with normal mobility. In this case, both cords are involved.

 

Option C. T2: Incorrect. T2 tumors extend to supraglottis and/or subglottis, or are associated with impaired vocal cord mobility. There is no extension and mobility is normal here.

 

Option D. T3: Incorrect. T3 is when there's vocal cord fixation or paraglottic space invasion or minor thyroid cartilage erosion. Again, none of these features are present.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

T1b glottic carcinoma involves both vocal cords with normal mobility and no spread beyond the glottis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 308

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker presents with progressive dyspnea and hoarseness. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals a subglottic mass, and imaging confirms extension to both vocal cords with normal vocal cord mobility. There is no evidence of cartilage erosion or extra-laryngeal spread. What is the T-stage of this subglottic cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T2

 

T2 subglottic tumors extend to the vocal cords, and may have normal or impaired mobility. In this scenario, vocal cord mobility is preserved, fitting the T2 criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T1: Incorrect. T1 subglottic tumors are strictly limited to the subglottis without extension to vocal cords. In this case, the tumor extends to the vocal cords, so T1 is ruled out.

 

Option C. T3: Incorrect. T3 indicates vocal cord fixation (i.e., no mobility), or more extensive local invasion. But the cords are mobile, so this is not T3.

 

Option D. T4a: Incorrect. T4a subglottic tumors invade cartilage or tissues beyond the larynx like trachea, esophagus, thyroid, or muscles. There's no evidence of such invasion in this case.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

T2 subglottic laryngeal carcinoma involves extension to vocal cords with normal or impaired mobility, without fixation or extralaryngeal spread.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 308

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with biopsy-proven laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma presents with a palpable left cervical lymph node measuring 5.5 cm. Imaging reveals no other nodal involvement, and there is no contralateral or bilateral lymphadenopathy. What is the correct N-stage of this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) N2a

 

N2a is defined as a single ipsilateral lymph node that is >3 cm but ≤6 cm. Fits exactly with this patient’s presentation (5.5 cm).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. N1: Incorrect. N1 refers to a single ipsilateral lymph node ≤3 cm in greatest dimension. This patient’s node is 5.5 cm, so N1 is excluded.

 

Option C. N2b: Incorrect. N2b involves multiple ipsilateral nodes, none >6 cm. But only one node is involved here, not multiple.

 

Option D. N3: Incorrect. N3 is defined as any lymph node >6 cm. Since the node is 5.5 cm, this doesn’t qualify as N3.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

N2a indicates metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node >3 cm but ≤6 cm in size.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 309

questions.text: A 64-year-old chronic smoker presents with hoarseness and difficulty breathing. Laryngoscopy reveals a tumor with vocal cord fixation and invasion of the paraglottic space. CT scan shows a single ipsilateral lymph node measuring 4 cm, and no distant metastasis. What is the clinical stage grouping of this laryngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage IVA

 

  • T3 + N2a + M0 exactly matches one of the combinations listed under Stage IVA.
  • T3: Tumor with vocal cord fixation and/or paraglottic space invasion
  • N2a: Single ipsilateral lymph node >3 cm but ≤6 cm
  • M0: No distant metastasis
  • Looking at the Stage Grouping table:
    • T3 + N2a + M0 ⟶Stage IVA

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage III: Incorrect. Stage III includes T3 only with N0 or N1 nodes. This patient has N2a → not Stage III.

 

Option C. Stage IVB: Incorrect. Requires T4b, N3, or worse involvement. Not applicable here.

 

Option D. Stage IVC: Incorrect. Reserved for M1 disease (distant metastasis), which is not seen here.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stage IVA includes T3–T4a tumors with N2 nodal status and no distant metastasis (M0).

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 309

choices.text: Nodal metastases are late and usually unilateral
Pre-epiglottic space involvement can lead to thyroid cartilage invasion
Most common site is aryepiglottic fold followed by epiglottis

questions.text: A 58-year-old male smoker presents with throat pain, progressive difficulty in swallowing, and recent weight loss. On examination, a mass is noted in the epiglottic region. No hoarseness is reported. Indirect laryngoscopy confirms a supraglottic growth involving the infrahyoid epiglottis. Which of the following statements is true regarding supraglottic carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pre-epiglottic space involvement can lead to thyroid cartilage invasion

 

Cancers of the infrahyoid epiglottis and anterior ventricular band can extend into the pre-epiglottic space, and from there may penetrate the thyroid cartilage, making it an important factor in staging and treatment planning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nodal metastases are late and usually unilateral: Incorrect. Nodal metastases in supraglottic cancer occur early, often involving upper and middle jugular nodes, and may be bilateral, especially in epiglottic cancers.

 

Option B. Hoarseness is the earliest symptom: Incorrect. Hoarseness is actually a late symptom in supraglottic cancers because the vocal cords are usually not involved in early disease.

 

Option D. Most common site is aryepiglottic fold followed by epiglottis: Incorrect. The most common sites in order are epiglottis, false cords, and then aryepiglottic folds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In supraglottic carcinoma, early nodal spread and pre-epiglottic space invasion are common, while hoarseness appears late in the course of disease.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 309

choices.text: Nodal metastasis is common in early glottic cancer
Involvement of thyroarytenoid muscle leads to cord fixation
The posterior third of vocal cord is the most common site

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents with persistent hoarseness of voice for the past 3 months. He denies any throat pain or dysphagia. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals a lesion over the anterior and middle third of the right vocal cord. Vocal cord mobility is preserved. Which of the following is TRUE regarding glottic carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Involvement of thyroarytenoid muscle leads to cord fixation

 

Fixation of the vocal cord occurs when the thyroarytenoid muscle is involved, and this is considered a poor prognostic sign.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nodal metastasis is common in early glottic cancer: Incorrect. Vocal cords have few lymphatics, so nodal metastasis is rare unless the lesion extends beyond the membranous cord.

 

Option B. Hoarseness is a late symptom: Incorrect. Hoarseness is an early symptom in glottic cancer because the vibratory function of the cord is directly affected.

 

Option D. The posterior third of vocal cord is the most common site: Incorrect. The anterior and middle third of the vocal cord (particularly the free edge and upper surface) are the most frequent sites of glottic carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In glottic cancer, hoarseness is an early sign, nodal metastasis is rare, and cord fixation due to thyroarytenoid muscle involvement indicates poor prognosis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 309

choices.text: Lymphatic spread involves upper cervical nodes initially
Upward spread to glottis occurs early in the disease
Stridor may be the initial presentation but often occurs late

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with gradually progressive breathing difficulty over several months. He is a chronic smoker. There is no hoarseness of voice initially, but recent indirect laryngoscopy shows a lesion below the vocal cords extending towards the cricoid. Which of the following statements about subglottic carcinoma is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stridor may be the initial presentation but often occurs late

 

Stridor can be the earliest observed symptom, but by the time it appears, the lesion has usually advanced significantly and encroached the airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hoarseness is the earliest symptom: Incorrect. Hoarseness is a late symptom in subglottic cancer and typically suggests involvement of the undersurface of vocal cords or the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Option B. Lymphatic spread involves upper cervical nodes initially: Incorrect. Subglottic cancer spreads to prelaryngeal, pretracheal, paratracheal, and lower jugular nodes, not the upper cervical nodes.

 

Option C. Upward spread to glottis occurs early in the disease: Incorrect. Upward spread is late, which is why hoarseness is delayed in presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subglottic carcinoma presents late, with stridor or airway obstruction often being the first noticeable symptom; hoarseness indicates glottic involvement and occurs later.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 309

choices.text: Early vocal cord fixation is characteristic of glottic cancer
Lymphatic spread is common in glottic cancer even in early stages
Hoarseness is an early symptom in glottic cancer but late in others
Subglottic cancer commonly causes early hoarseness due to recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement

questions.text: A 58-year-old male smoker presents with a 3-month history of hoarseness of voice. There is no pain, dysphagia, or neck swelling. Laryngoscopic examination reveals a lesion over the anterior two-thirds of the right true vocal cord with normal mobility. CT shows no subglottic or supraglottic extension and no lymphadenopathy. Which of the following best differentiates this lesion from supraglottic and subglottic cancers?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hoarseness is an early symptom in glottic cancer but late in others

 

In glottic cancer, hoarseness occurs early due to involvement of vibratory part of the vocal cord. In supraglottic and subglottic cancers, hoarseness occurs late, only after the lesion invades the vocal cord or adjacent structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early vocal cord fixation is characteristic of glottic cancer: Incorrect. Vocal cord fixation is a late finding and a bad prognostic sign, occurring when tumor invades the thyroarytenoid muscle. Early glottic cancer preserves mobility.

 

Option B. Lymphatic spread is common in glottic cancer even in early stages: Incorrect. Glottic region has few lymphatics, so nodal spread is rare in early glottic cancer, unlike supraglottic cancers which have rich lymphatic drainage.

 

Option D. Subglottic cancer commonly causes early hoarseness due to recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement: Incorrect. Subglottic cancer causes late hoarseness, often when the lesion invades undersurface of vocal cords or affects the recurrent laryngeal nerve. Early symptoms may include stridor or airway obstruction.

 

Quick Comparison Table:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glottic cancer presents early with hoarseness, due to direct involvement of vocal cords; in contrast, supraglottic and subglottic cancers often present late with hoarseness, after local extension.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 309

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker presents with progressive hoarseness for the past 6 weeks. Indirect laryngoscopy shows a thickened lesion over the right vocal cord with reduced mobility. No lymphadenopathy is noted on clinical examination. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the extent of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Direct laryngoscopy with biopsy

 

Gold standard for diagnosis. It allows direct visualization of hidden areas like anterior commissure, subglottis, and ventricles, and enables biopsy for histopathological confirmation. Especially essential when vocal cord mobility is reduced, suggesting deep infiltration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-ray soft tissue neck lateral view: Outdated for primary diagnosis. While it can show lesions involving the epiglottis or pre-epiglottic space, it is less sensitive than CT or MRI and does not confirm diagnosis.

 

Option B. MRI neck: MRI is more useful in recurrent lesions, especially post-radiotherapy, or in soft tissue detail. It is not the first-line for diagnosis in a new suspected case.

 

Option D. Flexible fibreoptic nasolaryngoscopy: Useful for outpatient visualization and documentation, but it does not allow biopsy, which is necessary for confirmation of malignancy.

 

Key Diagnostic Steps in Laryngeal Cancer:

 

  • History: Persistent hoarseness > 3 weeks in at-risk patients = red flag
  • Indirect laryngoscopy: Site & appearance of lesion + vocal cord mobility
  • Direct laryngoscopy with biopsy: Essential to visualize hidden areas and confirm diagnosis
  • CT scan: Best for assessing local spread, pre-epiglottic/paraglottic involvement, cartilage erosion
  • MRI: Best for post-radiotherapy assessment or soft tissue delineation
  • Neck exam: For nodal spread, thyroid cartilage, and strap muscle invasion
  • Microlaryngoscopy: Especially useful for small vocal cord lesions
  • Toluidine blue staining: Helps identify carcinoma in situ in leukoplakic lesions

 

Educational Objective:

 

Direct laryngoscopy with biopsy is the definitive investigation for diagnosing laryngeal cancer and assessing hidden areas of the larynx.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 310

questions.text: During an indirect laryngoscopy of a 62-year-old chronic smoker with hoarseness for 2 months, the ENT surgeon notes a granulation tissue-like lesion at the anterior commissure and restricted mobility of the right vocal cord. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this clinical finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Granulation tissue at the anterior commissure is a possible presentation of malignancy

 

Granulation tissue appearance at the anterior commissure can be a sign of laryngeal carcinoma in that region. It is one of the classical indirect laryngoscopic signs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The lesion likely arises from the suprahyoid epiglottis and is ulcerative in nature: Incorrect. Lesions of the suprahyoid epiglottis are usually exophytic, while ulcerative lesions are seen in infrahyoid epiglottis.

 

Option B. The observed lesion is typical of subglottic cancer which shows early hoarseness: Incorrect. Subglottic cancers usually present late with stridor or airway obstruction; hoarseness is a late feature due to delayed vocal cord involvement.

 

Option D. Impaired vocal cord mobility is an incidental finding and does not indicate deep infiltration: Incorrect. Impaired or fixed vocal cord is a critical sign of deep infiltration, involving structures like the thyroarytenoid muscle, cricoarytenoid joint, or recurrent laryngeal nerve. It is never incidental in suspected malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

On indirect laryngoscopy, anterior commissure malignancy may appear as granulation tissue, and vocal cord fixation indicates deep infiltration.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 310

choices.text: Soft tissue lateral view of neck

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a history of chronic smoking presents with hoarseness and neck swelling. Indirect laryngoscopy shows a suspicious lesion involving the supraglottic region. The ENT surgeon orders imaging to assess the extent of the tumor and any deeper invasion. Which of the following is the most appropriate radiological investigation to evaluate cartilage destruction and pre-epiglottic space involvement?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Contrast-enhanced CT scan

 

CT scan is the investigation of choice to assess:

 

  • Extent of tumor
  • Involvement of pre-epiglottic and paraglottic space
  • Destruction of laryngeal cartilages
  • Cervical lymph node involvement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest X-ray: Incorrect. Chest X-ray is important for identifying coexisting pulmonary disease, metastasis, or mediastinal nodes, but not ideal for local tumor assessment.

 

Option B. Soft tissue lateral view of neck: Incorrect. This older method can show lesions of the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and thyroid cartilage destruction, but has been superseded by more advanced cross-sectional imaging like CT and MRI.

 

Option D. MRI of the neck: Partially correct. MRI is better for soft tissue delineation and recurrent tumors post-radiotherapy, but CT is superior for cartilage evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT scan is the preferred imaging modality for assessing extent of laryngeal cancer, cartilage destruction, and lymph node involvement.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 310

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker presents with persistent hoarseness. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals a leukoplakic patch on the vocal cord. To guide biopsy and differentiate between benign and malignant areas within the patch, which of the following techniques is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Toluidine blue staining

 

This is a supravital stain used during microlaryngoscopy to differentiate:

 

  • Carcinoma in situ and superficial carcinomas → take up the dye.
  • Leukoplakia → does NOT take up the dye.
  • This helps select the biopsy site for maximum diagnostic accuracy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT scan: Incorrect. CT is useful for evaluating the extent of tumor and cartilage involvement but does not help identify malignant focus within a leukoplakic patch.

 

Option C. Chest X-ray: Incorrect. Useful for ruling out pulmonary metastases or coexistent lung disease, not diagnostic of lesion malignancy.

 

Option D. Laryngofissure with blind biopsy: Incorrect. It is an outdated and invasive technique. Biopsy should be directed, not blind—preferably via microlaryngoscopy with dye-guided selection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toluidine blue staining helps select malignant areas within leukoplakic lesions by staining carcinoma in situ or superficial cancer, while sparing benign leukoplakia.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 310

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with hoarseness for 2 months is diagnosed with an early-stage glottic carcinoma. Indirect laryngoscopy shows a small vocal cord lesion without any impairment of cord mobility or nodal involvement. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Curative Radiotherapy

 

Early-stage glottic cancer without cord fixation or cartilage involvement responds well to radiotherapy:

 

  • Offers 90% cure rates
  • Preserves voice
  • Best for small, superficial, mobile cord lesions

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chemotherapy: Incorrect. Chemotherapy is not the primary modality for early-stage glottic cancers. It is reserved for advanced or metastatic disease and is usually used in combination with radiotherapy.

 

Option C. Total Laryngectomy: Incorrect. This is indicated in advanced stage cancers, especially with cartilage invasion, cord fixation, or extensive subglottic extension.

 

Option D. Neck Dissection followed by Radiotherapy: Incorrect. This is for cases with nodal metastasis, which is not present here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early-stage glottic cancer without cord fixation or nodal involvement is best treated with curative radiotherapy, offering high cure rates and voice preservation.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 311

questions.text: A 62-year-old chronic smoker presents with hoarseness, stridor, and a mass involving both arytenoids and posterior commissure. Vocal cords are fixed on laryngoscopy. Imaging shows invasion of cricoid cartilage. What is the best surgical option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Total laryngectomy

 

Indicated when:

 

  • Cord is fixed (T4)
  • Invasion of cricoid/thyroid cartilage
  • Bilateral arytenoid involvement
  • Posterior commissure lesions
  • Failure of conservative treatment
  • Transglottic tumors

 

This surgery removes the entire larynx, strap muscles, part of trachea, and pre-epiglottic space, creating a permanent tracheostome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiotherapy: Incorrect. While effective in early lesions, it is not suitable for:

 

  • Cord fixation (T4 lesions)
  • Cricoid cartilage invasion
  • Bilateral arytenoid or posterior commissure involvement

 

Option B. Supraglottic laryngectomy: Incorrect. This conserves vocal cords and is only used for isolated supraglottic tumors without:

 

  • Cord fixation
  • Cartilage invasion
  • Posterior commissure involvement

 

Option C. Cordectomy via laryngofissure: Incorrect. Suitable only for very early cordal lesions, not when the cord is fixed or there is extensive spread.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total laryngectomy is indicated in advanced laryngeal cancers with cord fixation, cartilage invasion, bilateral arytenoid/posterior commissure involvement, or failed radiotherapy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 310

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with hoarseness of voice is diagnosed with T1 glottic carcinoma involving the mobile membranous vocal cord. There are no nodal metastases. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment with the least morbidity and shortest treatment duration?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endoscopic CO₂ laser excision

 

This is now a standard option for T1 glottic carcinoma involving mobile vocal cords. Advantages include:

 

  • Precision excision under microscope
  • Lower cost
  • Less morbidity
  • Shorter treatment duration
    It is also used for selected T1-T2 supra- or infrahyoid epiglottic lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiotherapy: Though traditionally the treatment of choice for early T1 glottic carcinoma, it involves longer treatment duration, higher cost, and potential radiation side effects.

 

Option B. Total laryngectomy: This is reserved for advanced lesions (T3/T4) or failed conservative therapy. It is unnecessarily aggressive for early-stage, mobile cord lesions.

 

Option D. Supraglottic laryngectomy: Used for supraglottic cancers, not suitable for glottic lesions like this one.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic CO₂ laser excision is a preferred modality for T1 glottic cancer involving mobile vocal cords due to its low morbidity, precision, and short treatment duration.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 310

choices.text: Radiotherapy to the primary with neck node irradiation

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with hoarseness of voice for the past 2 months. Laryngoscopy reveals a lesion involving the anterior commissure of the glottis with impaired vocal cord mobility. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. There is no cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the best initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Conservation laryngectomy

 

For T2 glottic carcinoma with:

 

  • Impaired cord mobility
  • Anterior commissure or arytenoid involvement
  • The preferred initial treatment is conservation laryngectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiotherapy to the primary with neck node irradiation: This is recommended only when the cord is mobile in T2 lesions. It is not the best Option involved, as in this case.

 

Option B. Total laryngectomy with neck dissection: This is considered when conservation surgery fails, not as the first-line treatment for T2N0 glottic cancer.

 

Option D. Endoscopic CO₂ laser excision: Ideal for T1 mobile cord lesions. Not suitable for T2 lesions with impaired mobility or anterior commissure involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

T2N0 glottic cancers with impaired cord mobility or anterior commissure involvement are best managed initially with conservation laryngectomy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 311

questions.text: A 55-year-old male chronic smoker presents with mild hoarseness of voice for the past 3 months. Flexible laryngoscopy reveals a suspicious lesion over the anterior vocal cord. Biopsy confirms carcinoma in situ. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transoral CO₂ laser excision

 

This is the treatment of choice for carcinoma in situ of the glottis. It allows precise removal of the lesion, preserves voice, and avoids over-treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiotherapy to the larynx: Radiotherapy is reserved for invasive carcinoma, not carcinoma in situ if a CO₂ laser or endoscopic approach is available.

 

Option B. Total laryngectomy: Not indicated in carcinoma in situ. This radical surgery is reserved for more advanced stages like T3/T4 lesions or failed conservative treatment.

 

Option D. Immediate chemotherapy: Chemotherapy is not used for isolated carcinoma in situ of the glottis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carcinoma in situ of the glottis is best treated by transoral CO₂ laser excision; biopsy confirmation guides further management.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 310

choices.text: Radiotherapy to the larynx including upper neck nodes

questions.text: A 58-year-old male smoker presents with hoarseness lasting over 1 month. Flexible laryngoscopy shows an exophytic lesion over the anterior two-thirds of the right vocal cord involving the anterior commissure. Vocal cord mobility is preserved. There is no palpable neck node. CT scan shows no cartilage erosion or nodal involvement. Biopsy reveals squamous cell carcinoma. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radiotherapy to the larynx including upper neck nodes

 

This case describes T₂N₀ glottic carcinoma with anterior commissure involvement but normal vocal cord mobility.

 

Let’s analyze each part:

 

  • Glottic origin = Most common site for laryngeal cancer
  • Anterior commissure involvement = Common extension path for glottic tumors
  • Vocal cord mobility normal = Favors better prognosis and suitability for radiotherapy
  • No nodal metastasis (N₀) = Common in glottic tumors due to sparse lymphatics
  • No cartilage erosion = Radiotherapy remains effective in early-stage glottic cancers

 

According to standard T₂N₀ treatment algorithm, radiotherapy is the first-line treatment if vocal cord mobility is intact and anterior commissure is involved (in select cases), with regular follow-up.

 

 

Best initial treatment for T₂N₀ glottic cancers with mobile cords. Radiation field includes primary and upper neck prophylactically.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total laryngectomy with neck dissection: Over-treatment for early-stage disease; reserved for T₃/T₄ lesions or recurrence after conservative measures.

 

Option C. Endoscopic CO₂ laser excision: Ideal for T₁ lesions or carcinoma in situ. Not the best choice when commissure is involved in T₂.

 

Option D. Conservation laryngectomy: This is used only when cord mobility is impaired or in radiation-failed cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice in T₂N₀ glottic cancer when vocal cord mobility is preserved and no nodal disease is present.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 310

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of chronic smoking presents with progressive breathing difficulty and stridor. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals a submucosal lesion below the vocal cords. CT scan confirms a lesion limited to the subglottic region with vocal cord fixation and no distant metastasis. No cervical lymphadenopathy is noted. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Total laryngectomy with postoperative radiotherapy

 

This is a classic presentation of a T₃ subglottic carcinoma with vocal cord fixation, indicating deeper infiltration and more advanced disease.

 

  • Let’s analyze each part:
    • Subglottic cancer = Rarest type of laryngeal cancer (1–2%)
    • Vocal cord fixation = Indicates T₃ or higher
    • T₁–T₂ lesions = Treated by radiotherapy
    • T₃–T₄ lesions = Treated by total laryngectomy followed by postoperative radiotherapy
    • Radiation field = Should include superior mediastinum due to lymphatic drainage in subglottic cancers

 

Standard treatment for T₃–T₄ subglottic cancers, especially when vocal cord is fixed or cartilage is involved. Radiation field includes the superior mediastinum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoscopic CO₂ laser excision: Not appropriate for deep submucosal or T₃ lesions; suitable only for superficial, early glottic disease.

 

Option B. Radiotherapy alone: Used for early T₁–T₂ subglottic lesions. Not sufficient when there is vocal cord fixation (T₃).

 

Option D. Partial horizontal laryngectomy: Not suitable for subglottic cancers with cord fixation or deep infiltration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

T₃–T₄ subglottic cancers are treated by total laryngectomy followed by radiotherapy, with the radiation field including the superior mediastinum.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 310

choices.text: Radiotherapy to the primary site and neck

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with dysphagia and muffled voice for the past 2 months. On indirect laryngoscopy, a supraglottic mass involving the epiglottis and false vocal cords is seen. Vocal cords are mobile. Neck examination reveals no palpable lymph nodes. CT scan shows no cartilage invasion or pre-epiglottic space involvement. Lung function tests are within normal limits. What is the most appropriate management option?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Supraglottic laryngectomy

 

This case describes a T₂N₀ supraglottic carcinoma with preserved cord mobility and no nodal involvement or cartilage/pre-epiglottic space invasion.

 

  • Let’s analyze each part:
    • Supraglottic site (epiglottis, false cords) involved = Common presentation
    • Cord mobility normal = Indicates earlier stage and operability
    • No cartilage invasion/pre-epiglottic space involvement = Supports conservative surgery
    • Good lung function = Makes the patient a suitable candidate for supraglottic laryngectomy
    • No nodal involvement (N₀) = Neck dissection may be deferred or selectively considered

 

Best suited for T₂ supraglottic lesions with mobile vocal cords and good pulmonary reserve.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total laryngectomy with neck dissection: Reserved for T₃/T₄ lesions or in cases of failed conservative treatment or cartilage invasion.

 

Option B. Radiotherapy to the primary site and neck: Acceptable in patients unfit for surgery, such as with poor lung function, but not first-line here.

 

Option D. Endoscopic CO₂ laser excision: More appropriate for T₁ superficial lesions. Not standard for T₂ lesions involving multiple supraglottic subsites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

T₂ supraglottic cancers with good lung function and mobile vocal cords are best treated by supraglottic laryngectomy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 311

questions.text: A 62-year-old male underwent total laryngectomy for advanced glottic carcinoma. On follow-up, he is unable to speak and is concerned about restoring communication. He is willing to try various techniques. He has failed to learn oesophageal speech. What is the most appropriate next step for vocal rehabilitation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Electrolarynx

 

This patient is a post-laryngectomy case who has lost his natural voice due to removal of the larynx. Vocal rehabilitation is critical for improving quality of life after total laryngectomy.

 

Let’s analyze the options and associated rehabilitation methods:

 

  • Oesophageal speech: This is first-line for many patients and involves swallowing and belching out air to produce sound. However, this patient has failed this method.
  • Electrolarynx: A battery-operated device with a vibrating disc placed against the neck. It allows for intelligible speech without needing oesophageal air control. This is the next step after failed oesophageal speech.

 

 

  • Tracheo-oesophageal speech: More advanced technique using prosthesis (e.g., Blom-Singer valve) to shunt air from trachea to esophagus. Useful long-term, but not the immediate next step after failure of basic speech methods.

 

 

Best next step. Offers speech restoration for those who cannot learn oesophageal speech. Immediate and effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Surgical reconstruction of vocal cords: Not possible post-laryngectomy. The cords are removed. No role here.

 

Option C. Pharyngo-cutaneous fistula: This is a complication, not a therapeutic procedure.

 

Option D. Chemoradiation to enhance residual phonation: No residual phonation is possible after laryngectomy. This is not relevant in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Electrolarynx is the best method for speech rehabilitation in total laryngectomy patients who fail oesophageal speech.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 311

questions.text: A 60-year-old male who underwent total laryngectomy for T₄ glottic carcinoma is now undergoing voice rehabilitation. He was unable to learn oesophageal speech and found the electrolarynx unsatisfactory. The ENT team suggests placement of a voice prosthesis that allows air from the trachea to enter the esophagus while preventing aspiration of food into the trachea. Which of the following prostheses is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blom-Singer prosthesis

 

This case describes tracheo-oesophageal speech rehabilitation using a one-way valved prosthesis. This method involves redirecting expired air from the trachea into the esophagus, where it vibrates the pharyngeal mucosa and produces speech. The Blom-Singer prosthesis is a popular one-way valve that prevents aspiration and allows phonation.

 

It's a one-way tracheo-esophageal voice prosthesis used in laryngectomized patients. It allows air to pass into the esophagus while preventing food and liquids from entering the trachea.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Passy-Muir valve: This is a one-way speaking valve used in tracheostomy patients, not post-laryngectomy patients with TEP (tracheo-esophageal puncture).

 

 

Option C. Montgomery T-tube: Used for airway stenting in subglottic or tracheal stenosis. Not a voice prosthesis.

 

 

Option D. Pharyngeal obturator: Used in cleft palate or velopharyngeal insufficiency to close nasal air escape during speech. Irrelevant here.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blom-Singer prosthesis is a one-way voice prosthesis used in rachea-esophageal speech after total laryngectomy to prevent aspiration and restore phonation.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 311

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a nasal speech quality. The parent notes that the child says "baba" instead of "mama" and "dada" for "nana." There is no history of nasal discharge, fever, or allergy. On examination, adenoids are enlarged and nearly obstruct the nasopharynx. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyponasality due to adenoid hypertrophy

 

  • This child is demonstrating hyponasality (rhinolalia clausa), a speech disorder characterized by the lack of nasal resonance during pronunciation of nasal consonants like "m", "n", and "ng".
  • Substitution of oral sounds for nasal consonants (e.g., "baba" instead of "mama") is typical.
  • It occurs when there is nasal or nasopharyngeal obstruction, preventing airflow through the nose.
  • Adenoid hypertrophy is one of the most common causes in children.

 

Enlarged adenoids block the nasal passage, causing rhinolalia clausa (hyponasal speech).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypernasality due to cleft palate: Incorrect. Hypernasality involves excessive nasal resonance due to velopharyngeal incompetence, not obstruction.

 

Option C. Functional aphonia: Incorrect. This is a psychogenic voice disorder seen mostly in emotionally labile adolescents/adults, not due to structural obstruction.

 

Option D. Puberphonia: Seen in post-pubertal males with persistently high-pitched voice. Not related to nasal resonance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyponasality (rhinolalia clausa) is caused by obstruction of the nasal or nasopharyngeal passage, commonly due to adenoid hypertrophy.

 

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 315

choices.text: Hyponasality due to habitual speech pattern
Hypernasality due to congenital short soft palate

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the ENT clinic for persistent nasal speech. On examination, the child is found to have a congenitally short soft palate. There is no nasal obstruction, allergy, or adenoidal hypertrophy. Which of the following best explains the speech abnormality?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypernasality due to congenital short soft palate

 

  • Hypernasality (rhinolalia aperta) is caused by incomplete closure of the velopharyngeal port, allowing air to escape into the nasal cavity during speech, even for oral sounds.
  • A congenitally short soft palate is one of the anatomical causes.
  • It leads to velopharyngeal insufficiency, causing nasal escape of air during speech, resulting in hypernasality.

 

This is a direct and specific cause listed in Table 63.2 under hypernasality.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyponasality due to nasal polyp: Incorrect. Nasal polyps cause obstructive hyponasality, not hypernasality. No obstruction exists in this case.

 

Option B. Hyponasality due to habitual speech pattern: Incorrect. There is no nasal obstruction or speech pattern issue. The problem is anatomical and results in hypernasality.

 

Option C. Hypernasality due to velopharyngeal insufficiency: Technically correct, but not the most specific. The better answer is the exact anatomical cause: congenital short palate, which leads to velopharyngeal insufficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenitally short soft palate is a structural cause of hypernasality due to velopharyngeal insufficiency.

 

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 315

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought by his parents with complaints that his voice sounds “blocked” and lacks the usual nasal quality when he speaks, especially with words containing “m” and “n.” There is no history of surgery. Examination reveals enlarged adenoids and nasal congestion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyponasality (Rhinolalia clausa)

 

The child’s voice sounds “blocked” or denasalized, particularly for nasal sounds like "m," "n," and "ng", indicating a lack of nasal resonance, which is the hallmark of hyponasality.

 

Hyponasality (Rhinolalia clausa) is due to nasal or nasopharyngeal obstruction. Common causes include:

 

  • Adenoids
  • Nasal polyps
  • Nasal allergy
  • Common cold
  • Habitual or familial speech patterns

 

In this case, enlarged adenoids and nasal congestion explain the nasal blockage and resonance loss.

 

It results from nasal/nasopharyngeal obstruction—classic in children with adenoids, cold, allergy, or nasal polyps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Velopharyngeal insufficiency: Incorrect. Seen in hypernasality, not hyponasality. Here, there is failure to close off nasopharynx, causing excessive nasal escape of air.

 

Option B. Hypernasality (Rhinolalia aperta): Incorrect. This occurs when there’s too much nasal resonance, commonly seen in:

 

  • Cleft palate
  • Submucous cleft
  • Postadenoidectomy
  • Velopharyngeal dysfunction

 

Option D. Functional aphonia: Incorrect. This presents as complete loss of voice or whispering speech without structural abnormality, commonly seen in emotional young females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyponasality (Rhinolalia clausa) is caused by nasal or nasopharyngeal obstruction, such as adenoids, polyps, or cold, leading to loss of nasal resonance in speech.

 

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 315

choices.text: Reassure the parents that it will resolve on its own
Refer for speech therapy and supportive psychotherapy
Rule out palatal defects like submucous cleft or velopharyngeal insufficiency

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought by his parents with complaints of repeated interruptions in his speech. He hesitates to start words, sometimes repeats the same syllables or prolongs certain sounds. The child has also started showing excessive eye blinking and head nodding while trying to speak. His development is otherwise normal. There is a history of his parents frequently correcting his speech and showing concern since he was 3 years old. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Refer for speech therapy and supportive psychotherapy

 

  • This is a classic case of stuttering, a disorder of fluency of speech that presents as:
  • Hesitation to start speaking
  • Repetitions, prolongations, or blocks in speech
  • May be associated with secondary mannerisms such as facial grimacing, eye blinking, or head movements
  • The child is in the typical age group (2–6 years) where transient dysfluency is common, but this case has progressed into well-established stuttering due to parental overreaction and correction, which fixes the pattern and makes it persistent.
  • Treatment involves:
    • Speech therapy to improve fluency
    • Psychotherapy to build confidence, reduce fear of speaking
    • Parental education to prevent overreaction during early speech development

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start antipsychotic therapy: Incorrect. Stuttering is not a psychotic disorder and does not require antipsychotic medication.

 

Option B. Reassure the parents that it will resolve on its own: Incorrect. While early stuttering may resolve spontaneously, established stuttering with secondary mannerisms requires intervention, not reassurance alone.

 

Option D. Rule out palatal defects like submucous cleft or velopharyngeal insufficiency: Incorrect. These are causes of hypernasality, not fluency disorders. The patient has no features of nasal speech.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stuttering is a speech fluency disorder best managed with speech therapy and psychotherapy, especially when secondary mannerisms and parental overreaction are present.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 315

questions.text: A 45-year-old comatose patient with head trauma is admitted to the ICU. He is unable to clear secretions due to poor cough reflex. There is a risk of aspiration, and intermittent positive pressure ventilation is anticipated for several days. What is the most appropriate airway management option in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tracheostomy

 

  • This clinical scenario highlights multiple indications for tracheostomy, including:
    • Alternative airway in patients with compromised upper airway patency (head trauma, coma)
    • Removal of secretions in patients with impaired cough (coma, head injury, chest/abdominal trauma)
    • Aspiration prevention using a cuffed tracheostomy tube, especially when pharyngeal secretions or bleeding from upper airway may enter the trachea
    • Improved alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space and airflow resistance
    • Preferred route for IPPR (Intermittent Positive Pressure Respiration) if needed beyond 72 hours
    • Facilitating anesthesia in difficult airway cases (not directly relevant in this case, but a function of tracheostomy)

 

It reduces dead space, improves ventilation, helps with aspiration control, and allows suctioning of secretions. Also suitable for prolonged IPPR (>72h) and safer than long-term intubation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orotracheal intubation: Not ideal for prolonged ventilation beyond 72 hours. Also uncomfortable, has higher risk of laryngeal injury and poor secretion clearance in long term.

 

 

Option B. Nasotracheal intubation: Not preferred in comatose patients due to high risk of sinusitis, pressure necrosis, and aspiration. Also, still requires periodic bronchoscopy for secretion clearance.

 

 

Option C. Cricothyrotomy: Emergency procedure only. Not used for prolonged airway management or for suctioning secretions.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheostomy is preferred over intubation when long-term airway access is needed, especially in comatose patients with secretion retention, aspiration risk, or when IPPR is needed beyond 72 hours.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 316

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of multiple rib fractures following a road traffic accident develops progressively increasing dyspnea. He is unable to clear his tracheobronchial secretions effectively due to severe pain during coughing. What is the most appropriate next step in airway management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tracheostomy

 

  • This case describes a patient with retained secretions due to painful cough, a classic indication for tracheostomy. According to the classification in Table 64.1 of P.L. Dhingra, tracheostomy is indicated in:
    • Respiratory obstruction (infections, trauma, tumors, foreign body)
    • Retained secretions (coma, neurological disorders, painful coughing, aspiration)
    • Respiratory insufficiency (e.g., COPD, emphysema, bronchiectasis)
    • This patient has retained secretions and inability to cough effectively, secondary to pain from chest trauma, justifying tracheostomy for airway protection, suctioning, and prevention of pneumonia.

 

Indicated for retained secretions due to painful cough, improves clearance and respiratory function.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeated bronchoscopy for suctioning: Impractical and traumatic; requires expertise and multiple sessions. Tracheostomy allows safer and repeated suction access.

 

Option B. Oropharyngeal airway insertion: Not suitable in conscious patients and doesn't help with secretion clearance or ventilation.

 

 

Option D. Cricothyrotomy: Emergency airway access only. Not suitable for long-term airway management or secretion removal.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheostomy is indicated in cases of retained tracheobronchial secretions when effective coughing is impaired due to coma, neuromuscular weakness, or painful chest conditions.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 317

choices.text: High tracheostomy is the preferred method in all routine cases due to ease of access
Mid tracheostomy is contraindicated in laryngeal carcinoma
High tracheostomy can lead to subglottic stenosis, but is acceptable in laryngeal carcinoma
Low tracheostomy is safer due to fewer surrounding vascular structures

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with carcinoma of the larynx is planned for total laryngectomy. As part of the procedure, a tracheostomy is performed above the level of the thyroid isthmus. Which of the following statements regarding this approach is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High tracheostomy can lead to subglottic stenosis, but is acceptable in laryngeal carcinoma

 

  • Tracheostomy can be classified based on urgency (emergency, elective, permanent) and level (high, mid, low):
  • High tracheostomy: Performed above thyroid isthmus, violating first tracheal ring, which risks perichondritis of cricoid and subglottic stenosis. It is avoided in general but acceptable in carcinoma larynx as larynx will be removed anyway.
  • Mid tracheostomy: The preferred approach, done through 2nd/3rd tracheal ring, often requires thyroid isthmus division or retraction.
  • Low tracheostomy: Done below the isthmus, but risky due to depth, vessel proximity, and difficulty with tube positioning near suprasternal notch.

 

 

  • Additionally, tracheostomy can be:
    • Emergency: Done when airway is acutely blocked and intubation not feasible.
    • Elective: Preplanned, with therapeutic or prophylactic goals.
    • Permanent: E.g., bilateral abductor palsy, post-laryngectomy.
    • Percutaneous dilatational and mini (cricothyroidotomy) also exist for specific settings.

 

Although risky, it is acceptable when the entire larynx is being excised.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High tracheostomy is the preferred method in all routine cases: Incorrect. High tracheostomy is avoided in routine cases due to risk of subglottic stenosis; used only in specific indications like laryngeal carcinoma.

 

Option B. Mid tracheostomy is contraindicated in laryngeal carcinoma: Incorrect. Mid tracheostomy is not contraindicated, but high tracheostomy may be done if total laryngectomy is planned.

 

Option D. Low tracheostomy is safer due to fewer surrounding vascular structures: Incorrect. Low tracheostomy is more dangerous due to proximity to major vessels and difficult tracheal access.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High tracheostomy is avoided due to subglottic stenosis risk but is acceptable in laryngeal carcinoma where the entire larynx is removed.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 316

choices.text: Tracheostomy should be done immediately without any attempt at intubation
General anaesthesia is mandatory before all tracheostomies
Neck should be flexed to bring the trachea forward during tracheostomy
Endotracheal intubation should be attempted before tracheostomy, especially in children

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents to the emergency with increasing respiratory distress due to epiglottitis. The decision to perform a tracheostomy is taken. Which of the following statements regarding tracheostomy in this scenario is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endotracheal intubation should be attempted before tracheostomy, especially in children

 

  • Key procedural principles in tracheostomy include:
  • Endotracheal intubation first: In children and infants, intubation is attempted first whenever feasible, even in emergency situations, as their anatomy makes tracheostomy more technically challenging and hazardous.
  • Patient position: The patient lies supine with a pillow under the shoulders, causing neck extension—this helps to bring the trachea anteriorly and facilitates safer access.
  • Anaesthesia considerations:
    • Unconscious or emergency patients may not require anaesthesia.
    • In conscious patients, local infiltration with 1–2% lignocaine + adrenaline is given.
    • Sometimes, general anaesthesia with intubation may be used in elective cases.

 

This is standard practice due to the high risk of pediatric tracheostomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheostomy should be done immediately without any attempt at intubation: Incorrect. Intubation should always be attempted first, especially in infants and children, to avoid complications.

 

Option B. General anaesthesia is mandatory before all tracheostomies: Incorrect. In unconscious or emergency patients, local anaesthesia or even no anaesthesia may be used.

 

Option C. Neck should be flexed to bring the trachea forward during tracheostomy: Incorrect. Neck extension, not flexion, is used to bring trachea forward.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endotracheal intubation should always be attempted before tracheostomy, particularly in infants and children, to avoid procedural complications.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 317

choices.text: Division of the first tracheal ring to facilitate tube insertion
Ligation of the thyroid isthmus to expose the first ring
Avoidance of suturing skin incision tightly
Use of a transverse incision in emergency cases for better cosmesis

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with carcinoma larynx undergoes an elective tracheostomy before total laryngectomy. During the procedure, a vertical midline neck incision is taken from below the cricoid cartilage to above the sternal notch. After strap muscle separation and isthmus ligation, the surgeon incises the trachea between the 2nd and 3rd rings and inserts a tracheostomy tube. Which of the following intraoperative steps is most critical in preventing subcutaneous emhysema?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Avoidance of suturing skin incision tightly

 

The skin incision is left loose and not packed tightly to prevent subcutaneous emphysema, which can occur due to trapped air. This step is crucial post-tube insertion.

 

Other Options:

 

This question tests knowledge of the surgical steps and precautions during tracheostomy:

 

Option A. Division of the first tracheal ring: Incorrect. The first ring should never be divided as it lies just below the cricoid. Doing so may lead to perichondritis of cricoid cartilage and subglottic stenosis—a major complication post-tracheostomy.

 

Option B. Ligation of thyroid isthmus to expose the first ring: Incorrect. The isthmus is generally divided or displaced to expose the 2nd–3rd rings, not the first ring. Again, the first ring is intentionally avoided.

 

Option D. Use of a transverse incision in emergency cases for better cosmesis: Incorrect. Vertical midline incisions are preferred in emergencies for rapid access with minimal bleeding. Transverse incisions are cosmetically better but reserved for elective tracheostomy.

 

Educational Objective:


Avoiding division of the first tracheal ring and not suturing the skin tightly during tracheostomy are key steps in preventing complications like subglottic stenosis and subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 317

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with progressive stridor since birth. Flexible laryngoscopy reveals a glottic web, and imaging shows subglottic narrowing. Despite conservative management, the child develops respiratory distress requiring airway intervention. The decision is made to perform a tracheostomy. Which of the following is the most likely reason for tracheostomy in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glottic web

 

Glottic web is a congenital laryngeal lesion causing airway obstruction in infants below 1 year. It is one of the classic congenital indications for tracheostomy. Other congenital causes include subglottic haemangioma, subglottic stenosis, laryngeal cyst, and bilateral vocal cord paralysis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis: Incorrect. While this is a common cause of airway compromise in older children (due to inflammation), it is not a typical congenital lesion seen in infants below 1 year of age.

 

 

Option C. External laryngeal trauma: Incorrect. This is a traumatic cause typically seen in older children due to direct injury, not in neonates or infants.

 

Option D. Prolonged intubation: Incorrect. Though it is a frequent reason for tracheostomy in children, it usually arises after critical care admissions and is less common as a primary indication in neonates or infants with congenital airway anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:


In infants below 1 year, congenital lesions like glottic web, subglottic haemangioma, or bilateral vocal cord paralysis are common indications for tracheostomy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 317

choices.text: Circular excision of tracheal wall segment
Use of a soft silastic tracheostomy tube
Proper use of stay sutures on either side of trachea

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is scheduled for an elective tracheostomy due to congenital subglottic stenosis. The procedure is performed under general anaesthesia. During surgery, the neck is hyperextended and the trachea is incised deeply to insert the tube. Postoperatively, the infant develops respiratory distress, and imaging reveals pneumomediastinum and abnormal tube positioning. Which of the following intraoperative errors most likely contributed to these complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Excessive neck extension during positioning

 

Overextension of the neck in infants and children pulls thoracic structures (pleura, innominate vessels, thymus) into the neck. This can result in serious complications such as pneumomediastinum or misplacement of the tracheostomy tube too low near the suprasternal notch.

 

  • Additional surgical pearls:
    • The infant trachea is soft and compressible, making it prone to displacement and injury to recurrent laryngeal nerve or carotid artery.
    • General anaesthesia is preferred, and pre-insertion of an endotracheal tube or bronchoscope aids identification of the trachea.
    • The knife should not be inserted too deep—posterior wall or oesophagus may be injured, leading to tracheo-oesophageal fistula.
    • The tube should be of correct size, length, and curvature; wrong dimensions can lead to trauma or airway obstruction.
    • Always take a postoperative X-ray to confirm tube position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Circular excision of tracheal wall segment: Incorrect. Although excising a circular piece of the trachea is not recommended, it leads more to tracheal collapse or stenosis rather than immediate postoperative respiratory distress with pneumomediastinum. It is not the most likely error in this case.

 

Option B. Use of a soft silastic tracheostomy tube: Incorrect. Use of soft silastic or Portex tubes is recommended to minimize trauma. Metallic tubes, in contrast, cause more tissue damage and are avoided in children.

 

Option C. Proper use of stay sutures on either side of trachea: Incorrect. Placing silk sutures (stay sutures) on either side of the tracheal midline before incision is a correct step, as it helps identify the trachea and stabilize it during tube insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pediatric tracheostomy, overextension of the neck can pull thoracic structures into the neck, increasing the risk of complications like pleural injury or low tracheostomy placement.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 318

choices.text: Increase suction pressure and perform deeper catheter insertions
Remove both outer and inner tubes every 6 hours for cleaning
Apply suction only during catheter withdrawal using sterile technique
Avoid humidification and switch to room air to prevent moisture accumulation

questions.text: . A 4-year-old child undergoes tracheostomy for prolonged intubation. On postoperative day 1, the child develops mild respiratory distress with thick secretions blocking the tube. The nurse performs frequent suctioning but notices some bleeding. The inner cannula is cleaned regularly, and steam nebulization is being used. Which of the following corrective steps is most appropriate to prevent further mucosal injury and maintain airway hygiene?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Apply suction only during catheter withdrawal using sterile technique

 

To prevent suction-related trauma, suction should be applied only while withdrawing the catheter, not during insertion. This helps in safely clearing secretions without injuring the tracheal mucosa. Sterile technique with Y-connector suction catheters is advised.

 

Other Options:


This question tests knowledge of postoperative care following tracheostomy, particularly related to suctioning, humidification, tube management, and complications:

 

Option A. Increase suction pressure and perform deeper catheter insertions: Incorrect. High suction force and deep catheter insertions increase the risk of mucosal injury and bleeding, especially in pediatric patients with delicate tracheal walls. Instead, suctioning should be gentle and controlled.

 

Option B. Remove both outer and inner tubes every 6 hours for cleaning: Incorrect. The outer tube should not be removed for the first 3–4 days, as premature removal may disrupt the tract formation. Only the inner cannula should be cleaned as needed during this early postoperative period.

 

Option D. Avoid humidification and switch to room air to prevent moisture accumulation: Incorrect. Proper humidification is essential post-tracheostomy to prevent crusting and tracheitis. It can be achieved using steam tents, humidifiers, or ultrasonic nebulizers. In case of crusting, normal saline, Ringer’s lactate, or mucolytics like acetylcysteine may be instilled to loosen secretions.

 

Other key points:

 

  • Constant supervision is needed to monitor for bleeding, displacement, or tube blockage.
  • Communication aids (e.g., bell or paper pad) should be provided to the patient.
  • Cuffed tubes should be periodically deflated to avoid pressure necrosis or tracheal dilatation.

 

Educational Objective:


In tracheostomized patients, suction should be applied only during catheter withdrawal using sterile technique to prevent tracheal mucosal injury.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 318

choices.text: Observe the child overnight and attempt decannulation at home
Proceed with tracheostomy wound closure to prevent infection
Perform endoscopic evaluation of airway to look for obstruction
Repeat the decannulation trial the next day without any investigations

questions.text: A 3-year-old child with a history of prolonged tracheostomy for bilateral vocal cord paralysis is planned for decannulation. The tracheostomy tube is replaced with a smaller one and temporarily plugged, during which the child develops tachypnea and desaturation. The attempt is postponed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perform endoscopic evaluation of airway to look for obstruction

 

In cases of failed decannulation, causes such as granulation tissue, subglottic stenosis, tracheomalacia, or persistent disease must be ruled out. Endoscopic examination using a flexible or rigid scope under magnification helps identify and treat such obstructions before another trial.

 

Other Options:

 

This question tests understanding of safe decannulation principles and management of failed decannulation in children:

 

Option A. Observe the child overnight and attempt decannulation at home: Incorrect. Pediatric decannulation should never be attempted at home, especially after a failed trial. It must be conducted in a controlled hospital setting, preferably in an operation theatre, with anaesthetic and reintubation support.

 

Option B. Proceed with tracheostomy wound closure to prevent infection: Incorrect. Wound closure is premature here. Since decannulation failed, closure may worsen obstruction or mask signs of respiratory compromise. Wound closure is done only after successful and stable decannulation.

 

Option D. Repeat the decannulation trial the next day without any investigations: Incorrect. Repeating trials without addressing potential underlying causes can be dangerous. Evaluation must precede further attempts.

 

Other Key Points:

 

  • Tracheostomy should not be kept longer than necessary to avoid infections, granulations, stenosis, or unsightly scars.
  • Decannulation should be done in OT with facilities for reintubation: good headlight, laryngoscope, ET tubes, tracheostomy tray.
  • Monitoring post-decannulation includes watching for respiratory distress, tachycardia, and using oximetry and blood gases.
  • Causes of failed decannulation include:
    • Persistent original disease
    • Granulations at or below stoma
    • Tracheal oedema or subglottic stenosis
    • Incurving tracheal wall (stomal defect)
    • Tracheomalacia
    • Psychological dependence on tracheostomy

 

Educational Objective:

 

In children with failed decannulation, endoscopic evaluation of the airway is essential to identify obstructive causes like granulations or tracheomalacia.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 319

questions.text: A 2-year-old child underwent tracheostomy for subglottic stenosis. On the third postoperative day, the patient develops sudden respiratory distress and swelling over the neck and chest wall that crackles on palpation. What is the most likely cause of this complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subcutaneous emphysema

 

This is a classic intermediate complication occurring in the first few hours or days after tracheostomy. It results from air leak into subcutaneous tissues, often due to improper tube placement, tight skin suturing, or air tracking along fascial planes. Crepitus on palpation is characteristic.

 

Other Options:

 

This question evaluates the recognition of intermediate complications following tracheostomy:

 

Option A. Tracheo-oesophageal fistula: Incorrect. Although tracheo-oesophageal fistula is a late complication, usually due to knife injury or prolonged use of cuffed tubes, it does not present with subcutaneous crackling or rapid onset swelling. It causes aspiration and recurrent pneumonitis.

 

Option C. Aspiration of tracheostomy tube fragment: Incorrect. This is a late complication related to corrosion of the tube with aspiration of its parts. It usually occurs after weeks or months, and presents with airway obstruction or bronchial symptoms, not immediate subcutaneous swelling.

 

Option D. Laryngeal stenosis due to perichondritis: Incorrect. This is also a late complication, often occurring after prolonged use of the tube or trauma to the cricoid cartilage. It presents as progressive stridor or difficulty in decannulation, not acute swelling.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subcutaneous emphysema is an intermediate complication of tracheostomy presenting within days due to air leak into tissues, recognized by swelling and crepitus.
