Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 319

choices.text: Perform jaw thrust with neck extension in all cases
Perform jaw thrust while avoiding neck extension in case of spinal injury

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the emergency room with severe airway obstruction following an allergic reaction. The obstruction is so critical that there is no time for a formal tracheostomy. What is the most appropriate initial measure to relieve the airway?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Perform jaw thrust while avoiding neck extension in case of spinal injury

 

The jaw thrust maneuver is the quickest and safest way to relieve airway obstruction non-invasively. Neck extension should be avoided in trauma cases to prevent spinal cord damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perform jaw thrust with neck extension in all cases: Neck extension may worsen a cervical spine injury. It should not be done if spinal injury is suspected.

 

Option B. Immediately proceed to surgical cricothyrotomy: Cricothyrotomy is invasive and reserved for when basic airway maneuvers like jaw thrust fail. It is not the first step.

 

Option C. Administer corticosteroids and monitor airway: Steroids are useful for reducing inflammation, but they take time to act and are not effective for immediate relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jaw thrust is the first-line maneuver for emergency airway relief, and neck extension should be avoided in suspected spinal injuries.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 319

choices.text: Insert an oropharyngeal airway to displace the tongue anteriorly and ventilate with a snugly fitted face mask
Immediately insert a nasogastric tube to relieve airway obstruction
Perform tracheostomy before attempting any basic airway support
Begin mouth-to-mouth ventilation without any airway adjunct

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is found unconscious with signs of airway obstruction. You decide to maintain the airway until definitive care is available. Which of the following correctly describes the appropriate next step in airway management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Insert an oropharyngeal airway to displace the tongue anteriorly and ventilate with a snugly fitted face mask

 

This is the correct approach in initial airway management. The oropharyngeal airway helps lift the tongue away from the posterior pharyngeal wall, relieving obstruction due to tongue fall. Ventilation is done via a snug-fitting face mask covering both the nose and mouth, and an Ambu bag is used to deliver air or oxygen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immediately insert a nasogastric tube to relieve airway obstruction: Nasogastric tubes are for gastric decompression or feeding and do not aid in airway clearance or ventilation.

 

Option C. Perform tracheostomy before attempting any basic airway support: Tracheostomy is not the first-line in emergency airway management. Basic airway adjuncts like oropharyngeal airways should always be tried first unless there is complete obstruction.

 

Option D. Begin mouth-to-mouth ventilation without any airway adjunct: While it may be a temporary measure, mouth-to-mouth is suboptimal in professional settings. Airway adjuncts like oropharyngeal airways and Ambu bag ventilation are more effective and safer, especially in unconscious patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In emergency airway management, an oropharyngeal airway relieves soft tissue obstruction by displacing the tongue and enables effective ventilation via face mask and Ambu bag.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 319

choices.text: Oropharyngeal airway to relieve obstruction from tongue and pharynx
Nasogastric tube to bypass upper airway obstruction
Nasopharyngeal airway inserted transnasally into the hypopharynx
Endotracheal tube inserted orally under general anaesthesia

questions.text: A 25-year-old trauma patient is conscious but has partial airway obstruction due to posterior tongue fall. You decide to use an airway adjunct for relief. Which of the following is the most appropriate and best-tolerated airway device in this awake patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nasopharyngeal airway inserted transnasally into the hypopharynx

 

The nasopharyngeal airway (trumpet) is designed to relieve obstruction due to tongue or pharyngeal collapse. It is inserted through the nostril into the posterior hypopharynx and is better tolerated in awake patients compared to oropharyngeal airways, as it avoids the gag reflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oropharyngeal airway to relieve obstruction from tongue and pharynx: While oropharyngeal airways can relieve soft tissue obstruction, they are poorly tolerated in awake or semi-conscious patients and may trigger gag reflex or vomiting.

 

Option B. Nasogastric tube to bypass upper airway obstruction: Nasogastric tubes are not airway devices. They are meant for feeding or decompression and do not help relieve soft tissue obstruction in the upper airway.

 

Option D. Endotracheal tube inserted orally under general anaesthesia: This is not appropriate as a first-line bedside airway adjunct, especially when the patient is still breathing and conscious. Intubation is invasive and usually reserved for severe obstruction or respiratory failure.

 

Educational Objective:


Nasopharyngeal airway inserted transnasally is preferred in awake patients to relieve soft tissue obstruction, as it is better tolerated than oropharyngeal airway.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 319

choices.text: It is a nasopharyngeal airway used for long-term mechanical ventilation
It is primarily used for emergency cricothyrotomy in airway obstruction
It is a laryngeal mask airway used when mask ventilation is inadequate and intubation fails
It is a metallic tracheostomy tube commonly used in unconscious patients

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient undergoing elective surgery under general anesthesia is ventilated using the airway device shown in the image. The triangular distal end of the device fits snugly over the laryngeal inlet, allowing direct delivery of oxygen into the trachea. Which of the following statements is true regarding the use of this device?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is a laryngeal mask airway used when mask ventilation is inadequate and intubation fails

 

The image shows a laryngeal mask airway (LMA) — a supraglottic device with a triangular distal end that sits over the laryngeal inlet. It allows oxygen to be delivered directly into the trachea. LMAs are most commonly used in nonemergent anesthesia settings but are also valuable as a backup airway when mask ventilation fails and intubation is unsuccessful.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a nasopharyngeal airway used for long-term mechanical ventilation: Incorrect. Nasopharyngeal airways (trumpets) are flexible tubes passed through the nose, not devices with a laryngeal-sealing triangular tip. They do not allow direct oxygen delivery into the trachea.

 

Option B. It is primarily used for emergency cricothyrotomy in airway obstruction: Incorrect. Cricothyrotomy involves a surgical incision into the cricothyroid membrane. The device shown is non-surgical and used for supraglottic airway management.

 

Option D. It is a metallic tracheostomy tube commonly used in unconscious patients: Incorrect. Metallic tracheostomy tubes are inserted directly into the trachea through a tracheostomy stoma. The device in the image is an LMA, used without surgical access.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A laryngeal mask airway fits over the laryngeal inlet and is used to deliver oxygen when mask ventilation fails and endotracheal intubation is not possible.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 319

choices.text: Use of a 22G needle to minimize trauma
Directing the catheter cranially after insertion
Ensuring adequate expiration to prevent barotrauma
Inserting the catheter at the suprasternal notch

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient develops complete upper airway obstruction and cannot be intubated or ventilated via face mask. The team decides to perform an emergency transtracheal jet ventilation. Which of the following is the most critical precaution during this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ensuring adequate expiration to prevent barotrauma

 

A critical step in transtracheal jet ventilation is ensuring that air can escape during expiration. If not, air trapping can occur, leading to pulmonary barotrauma, such as pneumothorax, pneumomediastinum, or surgical emphysema.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Use of a 22G needle to minimize trauma: Incorrect. Jet ventilation requires a large-bore catheter (12–14G), not a fine needle. A smaller gauge would not allow adequate airflow for oxygenation.

 

Option B. Directing the catheter cranially after insertion: Incorrect. The catheter must be directed caudally (downward) into the trachea to allow proper jet ventilation. Cranial direction could lead to improper placement or injury.

 

Option D. Inserting the catheter at the suprasternal notch: Incorrect. The catheter is inserted through the cricothyroid membrane, not at the suprasternal notch. The cricothyroid membrane is accessible, especially in thin individuals.

 

Key procedural steps:

 

  • A 12 or 14G IV catheter with syringe is inserted through the cricothyroid membrane.
  • Aspiration confirms intratracheal placement, after which the needle is removed and jet ventilation initiated.
  • It is easier in thin patients where the trachea is palpable.
  • Expiration must be unobstructed to avoid life-threatening barotrauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During transtracheal jet ventilation, ensuring unobstructed expiration is essential to prevent barotrauma such as pneumothorax and surgical emphysema.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 319

choices.text: Endotracheal intubation using laryngoscope without anesthesia
Surgical tracheostomy performed immediately at bedside

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with rapidly progressing airway obstruction due to a laryngeal tumor. To secure the airway quickly, the team decides to avoid an emergency tracheostomy. Which of the following airway management methods is the most rapid and preferred in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endotracheal intubation using laryngoscope without anesthesia

 

Endotracheal intubation is the most rapid method of airway control. It involves direct visualization of the larynx using a laryngoscope and insertion of an endotracheal tube or bronchoscope. In emergencies, it can be done without anesthesia, making it preferable over a rushed tracheostomy, which has a higher complication rate. Once the airway is secured, an orderly tracheostomy can be planned if needed.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cricothyrotomy under general anesthesia: Incorrect. Cricothyrotomy is usually an emergency surgical procedure, reserved for when intubation fails. Administering general anesthesia can delay airway access and is not necessary for urgent intubation.

 

 

Option C. Surgical tracheostomy performed immediately at bedside: Incorrect. An emergency tracheostomy performed without airway control is riskier and associated with higher complication rates, especially in a distressed patient. Intubation is safer and faster.

 

 

Option D. Jet ventilation through suprasternal notch: Incorrect. Jet ventilation is typically done through the cricothyroid membrane, not the suprasternal notch, and is not the first-line method when the larynx can be visualized for intubation.

 

 

Key points:

 

  • Endotracheal intubation is rapid and avoids hurried tracheostomy complications.
  • It is done using laryngoscope or bronchoscope.
  • No anesthesia is needed in emergency settings.
  • Allows time for orderly tracheostomy after stabilization.

 

Educational Objective:


Endotracheal intubation is the fastest and safest initial method for airway control, avoiding rushed tracheostomy and its complications.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 320

choices.text: It provides long-term airway access and does not need tracheostomy
It is done through the tracheal rings and not the cricothyroid membrane
It is a temporary life-saving procedure; tracheostomy should be done soon after
It is an ideal method for clearing secretions after thoracic surgery

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with sudden upper airway obstruction and is in severe respiratory distress. Endotracheal intubation is not possible. The emergency team performs a vertical skin incision followed by a transverse cut through the cricothyroid membrane. Airway is maintained using a small tracheostomy tube. What is the most accurate statement regarding this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is a temporary life-saving procedure; tracheostomy should be done soon after

 

 

This procedure, whether called cricothyrotomy, laryngotomy, or mini tracheostomy, is done in emergencies to buy time until a definitive tracheostomy can be performed in the operation theatre. Commercial emergency kits may also be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It provides long-term airway access and does not need tracheostomy: Incorrect. Cricothyrotomy or mini-tracheostomy is not suitable for prolonged use due to risks of perichondritis, subglottic edema, and laryngeal stenosis. A formal tracheostomy should follow as soon as the patient is stable.

 

Option B. It is done through the tracheal rings and not the cricothyroid membrane: Incorrect. This procedure is specifically done through the cricothyroid membrane, located between the thyroid cartilage and cricoid cartilage — not through the tracheal rings.

 

Option D. It is an ideal method for clearing secretions after thoracic surgery: Incorrect. Elective mini-tracheostomy has been used to clear secretions after thoracic surgery, but this is not the purpose of emergency cricothyrotomy described in this question.

 

Additional Points from the Text:

 

  • Patient’s neck is extended, landmarks identified.
  • Vertical skin incision, then transverse incision through cricothyroid membrane.
  • A tube or even knife handle may be inserted if a tube isn’t available.
  • Cricothyroid needle puncture is another emergency method, but it does not ensure adequate ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cricothyrotomy is a temporary emergency procedure through the cricothyroid membrane and must be followed by a formal tracheostomy to prevent complications.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 320

choices.text: Tracheal incision should be made at the level of the first tracheal ring
Horizontal skin incision is preferred in emergencies for cosmesis
Emergency tracheostomy should always be preferred over endotracheal intubation
It is safer to attempt endotracheal intubation first to allow an orderly tracheostomy

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with rapidly worsening stridor and cyanosis. Endotracheal intubation is not possible, and an emergency tracheostomy is attempted at bedside. During the procedure, the neck is extended, a vertical incision is made from the lower border of the thyroid cartilage to the suprasternal notch, and the second and third tracheal rings are incised. Which of the following statements is true regarding this emergency procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is safer to attempt endotracheal intubation first to allow an orderly tracheostomy

 

If the airway can be secured via endotracheal intubation, it allows time for a planned tracheostomy to be performed in a controlled environment. Emergency tracheostomy on a struggling patient without adequate lighting, suction, or instruments is risky and associated with many complications.

 

Surgical Steps:

 

  • Extend the neck and fix the trachea between the surgeon’s fingers.
  • Make a vertical skin incision from the lower thyroid cartilage to the suprasternal notch.
  • Dissect down to the upper three tracheal rings, avoiding the first.
  • Incise pretracheal fascia and thyroid isthmus.
  • Make a vertical tracheal incision in the second and third rings and insert the tube.
  • Control bleeding by packing with gauze.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheal incision should be made at the level of the first tracheal ring: Incorrect. The first tracheal ring lies just below the cricoid cartilage and should be avoided, as injury here increases the risk of subglottic stenosis. The correct site is between the second and third tracheal rings.

 

Option B. Horizontal skin incision is preferred in emergencies for cosmesis: Incorrect. In emergency tracheostomy, a vertical incision is preferred as it allows quicker access and less bleeding, which is more important than cosmetic considerations.

 

Option C. Emergency tracheostomy should always be preferred over endotracheal intubation: Incorrect. Endotracheal intubation is safer and faster when possible and should always be attempted first before proceeding to surgical airway access, especially in emergencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endotracheal intubation should be attempted first to avoid the risks associated with emergency tracheostomy on an unprepared patient.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 321

choices.text: Tracheal entry should be made lateral to midline between first and second rings
It should be avoided in obese patients or when trachea is not easily palpable
It is done under general anesthesia with direct visualization of vocal cords
The main disadvantage is risk of nosocomial infection due to ICU setting

questions.text: A 65-year-old ICU patient on mechanical ventilation is scheduled for percutaneous dilatational tracheostomy (PDT). The neck is extended, and a flexible bronchoscope is inserted via the endotracheal tube to guide the needle and dilators. Which of the following statements regarding this procedure is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It should be avoided in obese patients or when trachea is not easily palpable

 

Percutaneous dilatational tracheostomy (PDT) is contraindicated in patients with obesity, neck masses, or where larynx and trachea are not easily palpable, as proper midline needle placement is critical. It is also avoided in uncorrectable coagulopathy or when the neck cannot be extended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheal entry should be made lateral to midline between first and second rings: Incorrect. Tracheal entry must be made in the midline between the second and third tracheal rings to avoid complications like paratracheal insertion or posterior tracheal wall injury. Entry lateral to midline is contraindicated.

 

Option C. It is done under general anesthesia with direct visualization of vocal cords: Incorrect. PDT is performed under sedation in ICU settings and is monitored via a flexible bronchoscope passed through the endotracheal tube—not by direct vocal cord visualization.

 

Option D. The main disadvantage is risk of nosocomial infection due to ICU setting: Incorrect. On the contrary, one advantage of PDT is avoiding transfer to OT, thereby reducing ICU nosocomial infection transmission and allowing earlier discharge.

 

Key steps and points from the procedure:

 

  • Patient is already intubated and monitored in ICU.
  • Done under sedation, with neck extended using a shoulder pad.
  • Incision made 2 cm below cricoid, entry between 2nd and 3rd tracheal rings.
  • Flexible bronchoscope guides placement.
  • Complications include paratracheal tube entry, posterior wall injury, hemorrhage, and surgical emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Percutaneous dilatational tracheostomy should be avoided in obese patients or when the trachea is not easily palpable due to high risk of complications.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 321

choices.text: Inhalation of peanut while crying or playing
Aspiration of tooth during general anesthesia
Accidental ingestion of a coin into the stomach
Nasal foreign body obstructing the nasopharynx

questions.text: A 2-year-old child suddenly develops bouts of coughing and wheezing while playing with peanuts. There is no history of fever. On examination, decreased air entry is noted on the right side. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhalation of peanut while crying or playing

 

Children under 4 years are at high risk of foreign body aspiration. Commonly during play or crying, they may suddenly inspire with an object in the mouth. Peanut is the most common vegetable foreign body in this age group, and this often leads to airway obstruction, especially in the right bronchus due to its anatomical alignment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspiration of tooth during general anesthesia: Incorrect. This is more common in adults, particularly during anesthesia, deep sleep, or coma, when airway protective reflexes are lost. It is not typical in a healthy, awake child.

 

Option C. Accidental ingestion of a coin into the stomach: Incorrect. While foreign body ingestion can happen in children, a coin in the stomach causes GI symptoms, not sudden coughing and wheezing or decreased air entry.

 

Option D. Nasal foreign body obstructing the nasopharynx: Incorrect. A nasal foreign body typically presents with foul-smelling nasal discharge or nasal obstruction, not acute respiratory symptoms like wheezing or decreased breath sounds.

 

Additional Key Points:

 

  • >50% of airway foreign body cases occur in children under 4 years.
  • Common vegetable FBs: peanut, almond seed, peas, beans, etc.
  • Common non-vegetable FBs: plastic toys, whistles, safety pins, nails, etc.
  • In adults: risk is during coma, intoxication, or anesthesia (e.g., loose teeth or dentures).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peanuts are the most common foreign bodies aspirated by children under 4, typically during play, crying, or sudden inspiration.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 321

choices.text: Aspiration of a nonirritating foreign body causing mechanical bronchial blockade
Inhalation of an irritating vegetable foreign body leading to edema and secondary infection
Bronchial asthma with associated mucus plugging
Congenital bronchial anomaly with impaired drainage

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with persistent cough, low-grade fever, and decreased air entry on the right side for the past 5 days. Chest X-ray shows signs of right lung consolidation. Parents recall the child playing with peanuts last week. Which of the following best explains the likely pathophysiological process?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inhalation of an irritating vegetable foreign body leading to edema and secondary infection

 

Vegetable foreign bodies such as peanuts, beans, seeds are irritating in nature. They cause diffuse inflammatory reaction, congestion, mucosal edema, and can swell over time, worsening the obstruction. This leads to a condition called "vegetal bronchitis" and may result in suppuration or consolidation if retained. This explains the delayed respiratory symptoms and lung findings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspiration of a nonirritating foreign body causing mechanical bronchial blockade: Incorrect. Nonirritating foreign bodies like plastic, glass, or metal may remain asymptomatic for long periods, often detected incidentally. They don’t typically cause inflammatory symptoms early.

 

Option C. Bronchial asthma with associated mucus plugging: Incorrect. Asthma presents with reversible bronchospasm, typically bilateral wheeze, and is not associated with localized consolidation or history of aspiration.

 

Option D. Congenital bronchial anomaly with impaired drainage: Incorrect. Congenital anomalies may predispose to recurrent infections but are less likely to present acutely after a specific choking event or foreign body history.

 

  • Areca nut is common in Rajasthan,
  • Peanuts in the USA,
  • Watermelon seeds in Egypt,
  • Pumpkin seeds in Greece.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vegetable foreign bodies are irritating, cause mucosal edema and inflammation ("vegetal bronchitis"), and may lead to airway obstruction and lung infection.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 321

choices.text: Bronchial foreign body causing obstructive emphysema
Pneumonia due to viral respiratory infection
Foreign body in the larynx causing stridor and aphonia

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought with a history of sudden onset of choking and coughing while eating peanuts. He was initially symptomatic but is now asymptomatic for the last 48 hours. On examination, breath sounds are decreased on the right side with hyperresonance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bronchial foreign body causing obstructive emphysema

 

  • The question describes the three stages of foreign body aspiration:
    • Initial choking and coughing,
    • A symptomless interval (here, 48 hours),
    • Development of later signs — in this case, hyperresonance and decreased breath sounds on the right side, which is the most common site for foreign body lodgement due to its straight, wider course.
    • Obstructive emphysema occurs due to check-valve mechanism, where air enters during inspiration but cannot escape during expiration, causing overinflation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pneumonia due to viral respiratory infection: Incorrect. Viral pneumonia typically presents with fever, cough, and bilateral findings, not sudden onset, a symptomless interval, and localized emphysema.

 

Option C. Foreign body in the larynx causing stridor and aphonia: Incorrect. Laryngeal foreign bodies cause immediate symptoms like hoarseness, aphonia, dyspnea, and possibly stridor. They are unlikely to cause a symptomless interval or signs of emphysema.

 

Option D. Congenital lobar emphysema: Incorrect. This is a congenital anomaly, usually diagnosed in infants, and does not have an acute choking episode or sudden symptom onset.

 

Key Concepts:

 

  • Three clinical stages of foreign body aspiration:
    • Initial choking/gagging/cough
    • Symptomless interval (hours to weeks)
    • Later symptoms based on site:
      • Larynx: hoarseness, aphonia, croupy cough, sudden death in total obstruction
      • Trachea: “audible slap,” “palpatory thud,” asthmatoid wheeze
      • Bronchus: Atelectasis, obstructive emphysema, spontaneous pneumothorax, lung abscess

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bronchial foreign bodies often present with initial choking, a symptom-free interval, followed by obstructive emphysema due to a check-valve mechanism.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 321

choices.text: Choking, palpatory thud, and audible slap
Cough, wheeze, and diminished air entry

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with sudden onset of cough, wheeze, and decreased air entry on the left side after playing with sunflower seeds. The child is now in mild respiratory distress, and imaging shows hyperinflation of the left lung. Which of the following triads is most characteristic of bronchial foreign body?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cough, wheeze, and diminished air entry

 

This classic triad of bronchial foreign body is the most commonly seen presentation in children. The right bronchus is most often involved, but it may also occur on the left side. Additional features can include respiratory distress, obstructive emphysema, or lung collapse depending on the degree of blockage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hoarseness, aphonia, and inspiratory stridor: Incorrect. This triad is suggestive of a laryngeal foreign body, where partial obstruction produces upper airway symptoms such as hoarseness, stridor, croupy cough, and sometimes aphonia.

 

Option B. Choking, palpatory thud, and audible slap: Incorrect. This triad is more typical of tracheal foreign body, where a mobile object moves between the vocal cords and carina. It may produce sounds like an audible slap and a palpable thud.

 

Option D. Fever, coryza, and bilateral rhonchi: Incorrect. These symptoms are typical of viral upper respiratory infections and do not correlate with foreign body aspiration, which usually presents with asymmetric signs and often a history of choking.

 

  • Larynx: Complete obstruction → death, or partial → stridor, hoarseness
  • Trachea: Choking, stridor, wheeze, cough, palpatory thud, audible slap
  • Bronchi: Triad of cough, wheeze, diminished air entry, later features include emphysema, lung collapse, bronchiectasis, lung abscess

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bronchial foreign bodies typically present with the triad of cough, wheeze, and diminished air entry, often accompanied by respiratory distress and late complications like emphysema or collapse.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 321

choices.text: High-resolution CT chest to visualize radiolucent objects
Expiratory chest X-ray or lateral decubitus film to detect obstructive emphysema
Administer bronchodilators and antibiotics, observe for 3 days

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with a history of sudden-onset cough and wheeze while eating peanuts. On auscultation, breath sounds are reduced on the right side. Chest X-ray PA view is normal. Which of the following is the best next step to evaluate a suspected bronchial foreign body?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Expiratory chest X-ray or lateral decubitus film to detect obstructive emphysema

 

In suspected bronchial foreign body, especially when the X-ray is normal, an expiratory chest X-ray or lateral decubitus film is very useful. It shows unilateral obstructive emphysema (a hyperlucent lung with mediastinal shift to the opposite side), which is an early indirect sign of a radiolucent foreign body. This technique is particularly useful in young children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat chest X-ray after 48 hours: Incorrect. Waiting may delay diagnosis. In the early phase or with radiolucent foreign bodies (like peanuts), the chest X-ray can appear normal, especially within the first 24 hours.

 

Option B. High-resolution CT chest to visualize radiolucent objects: Incorrect. Although CT can help, it is not the initial or most practical step in an uncooperative child. Also, it may still miss radiolucent foreign bodies and lacks dynamic expiratory evaluation.

 

Option D. Administer bronchodilators and antibiotics, observe for 3 days: Incorrect. This may delay definitive treatment and increase the risk of complications like pneumonitis, bronchiectasis, or lung abscess. Also, misdiagnosing foreign body aspiration as asthma is a common and dangerous error.

 

Diagnostic Highlights:

 

  • Sudden onset cough, wheeze, and decreased air entry is a classical triad.
  • X-ray findings:
    • Obstructive emphysema = early sign
    • Atelectasis = late sign
    • Mediastinal shift to opposite side in emphysema
    • PA expiratory view or lateral decubitus film shows hyperinflated lung
  • CT and fluoroscopy are also useful but usually second-line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Expiratory chest X-ray or lateral decubitus film is the best initial investigation for detecting obstructive emphysema in suspected radiolucent bronchial foreign body.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 322

choices.text: Administer bronchodilators and observe for improvement
Perform Heimlich manoeuvre as first aid
Attempt back blows in all cases including partial obstruction
Immediately take the child to the operation theatre for laryngofissure

questions.text: A 5-year-old child suddenly becomes aphonic while eating and shows signs of respiratory distress. He is unable to speak or cry. On examination, he is gasping and cyanotic. What is the most appropriate immediate step in managing this emergency?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perform Heimlich manoeuvre as first aid

 

The child is aphonic, gasping, and cyanotic—indicating complete airway obstruction likely due to a laryngeal foreign body above the vocal cords. The Heimlich manoeuvre is the recommended first aid, involving abdominal thrusts to generate positive pressure from the lungs to dislodge the object.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer bronchodilators and observe for improvement: Incorrect. Bronchodilators are used for asthma or bronchospasm, not for mechanical airway obstruction due to foreign bodies. Delay in intervention could be fatal.

 

Option C. Attempt back blows in all cases including partial obstruction: Incorrect. Back blows and Heimlich manoeuvre should not be performed if the airway is only partially obstructed, as this can convert a partial obstruction into a complete one.

 

Option D. Immediately take the child to the operation theatre for laryngofissure: Incorrect. Surgical removal by laryngofissure is a last resort, done after airway is secured. In emergency, first aid (Heimlich) is attempted first, followed by cricothyrotomy or emergency tracheostomy if Heimlich fails.

 

Key points:

 

  • Total obstruction = patient aphonic, cyanotic, unable to cry → risk of asphyxia
  • First aid = back blows, turning patient upside down, Heimlich manoeuvre
  • Heimlich: Stand behind patient, wrap arms around lower chest, give abdominal thrusts
  • If Heimlich fails → cricothyrotomy or emergency tracheostomy
  • Definitive removal = direct laryngoscopy or laryngofissure

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of complete airway obstruction due to laryngeal foreign body, Heimlich manoeuvre is the immediate life-saving first aid.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 322

choices.text: Flexible fibreoptic bronchoscopy under local anaesthesia
Rigid bronchoscopy under general anaesthesia with appropriate instruments
Administer corticosteroids and observe for spontaneous expulsion

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with history of peanut aspiration 3 days ago. Examination reveals decreased air entry on the right side with obstructive emphysema. The child is stable and cooperative. Which of the following is the most appropriate method for removal of the suspected bronchial foreign body?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rigid bronchoscopy under general anaesthesia with appropriate instruments

 

Rigid bronchoscopy under general anaesthesia is the standard method for removing tracheobronchial foreign bodies, especially in paediatric patients. Additional aids like telescopes, C-arm fluoroscopy, Dormia baskets, or Fogarty’s catheters may be used, depending on the object's shape and position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency tracheostomy followed by thoracotomy: Incorrect. Thoracotomy and bronchotomy are reserved for peripherally lodged foreign bodies that cannot be removed via bronchoscopy. They are not first-line, especially if the foreign body is accessible and the patient is stable.

 

Option B. Flexible fibreoptic bronchoscopy under local anaesthesia: Incorrect. Though used in selected adult patients, rigid bronchoscopy is the preferred method for children due to better airway control and larger working channels for instrument manipulation.

 

Option D. Administer corticosteroids and observe for spontaneous expulsion: Incorrect. This approach risks airway edema, infection, or worsening obstruction. Vegetable foreign bodies like peanuts may swell and cause more complications. Delay in removal is unsafe.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Foreign bodies in trachea or bronchi are removed under general anaesthesia via bronchoscopy, not in emergency unless there is obstruction or if it’s vegetable in nature (likely to swell).
  • Rigid bronchoscopy is the standard method.
  • Special tools: Dormia basket, Fogarty’s balloon, optical forceps, bronchoscopes in 3 sizes, and C-arm guidance.
  • In rare cases: tracheostomy first, or thoracotomy for peripheral objects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheobronchial foreign bodies are best removed by rigid bronchoscopy under general anaesthesia using age-appropriate instruments.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 322

choices.text: Direct laryngoscopy is contraindicated in young children with airway symptoms
Direct laryngoscopy is indicated when indirect laryngoscopy fails due to gag reflex
Direct laryngoscopy is first-line in moderate respiratory obstruction without tracheostomy
Direct laryngoscopy cannot be used for removal of laryngeal foreign bodies

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with hoarseness, stridor, and difficulty swallowing. Indirect laryngoscopy is not possible due to age. The ENT surgeon plans direct laryngoscopy under general anesthesia. Which of the following is true regarding indications or contraindications for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Direct laryngoscopy is indicated when indirect laryngoscopy fails due to gag reflex

 

When indirect laryngoscopy is not successful, especially due to exaggerated gag reflex or anatomical obstructions like an overhanging epiglottis, direct laryngoscopy becomes essential to visualize structures such as the ventricles, anterior commissure, or subglottis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct laryngoscopy is contraindicated in young children with airway symptoms: Incorrect. On the contrary, direct laryngoscopy is especially indicated in infants and young children, as indirect laryngoscopy is not possible in them. It allows evaluation of the larynx and hypopharynx in pediatric patients presenting with symptoms like stridor, dyspnea, hoarseness, and dysphagia.

 

Option C. Direct laryngoscopy is first-line in moderate respiratory obstruction without tracheostomy: Incorrect. In cases of moderate to severe respiratory obstruction, direct laryngoscopy is contraindicated unless the airway is already secured (e.g., by tracheostomy), as the procedure may worsen obstruction or cause respiratory arrest.

 

Option D. Direct laryngoscopy cannot be used for removal of laryngeal foreign bodies: Incorrect. Therapeutic indications for direct laryngoscopy include removal of benign laryngeal lesions and foreign bodies from the larynx and hypopharynx.

 

Indications Recap:

 

  • Diagnostic: When indirect laryngoscopy is not possible (infants, gag reflex), to examine hidden regions of larynx/hypopharynx, or to take biopsy of suspected growths.
  • Therapeutic: Removal of papillomas, polyps, nodules, foreign bodies, or for dilatation of strictures.
  • Contraindications:
    • Cervical spine disease/injury
    • Moderate/marked airway obstruction without tracheostomy
    • Recent MI or cardiac failure

 

Educational Objective:

 

Direct laryngoscopy is indicated when indirect laryngoscopy fails due to gag reflex or anatomical limitations and is contraindicated in moderate airway obstruction unless tracheostomy is done.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 422

choices.text: Neck fully extended with chin elevated and no head support
Supine with head flexed on thorax and extended at atlanto-occipital joint
Prone with head hanging down to align oral and laryngeal axes
Lateral position with head rotated to left to improve laryngeal exposure

questions.text: During direct laryngoscopy under general anaesthesia, the patient's position is adjusted to optimally visualize the larynx. Which of the following best describes the correct positioning for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Supine with head flexed on thorax and extended at atlanto-occipital joint

 

  • This is the ideal position for direct laryngoscopy and is known as the “barking dog position.” It is achieved by:
    • Placing a pillow (10–15 cm) under the occiput or raising the head flap of the table,
    • Flexing the neck on the thorax (lower cervical flexion), and
    • Extending the head at the atlanto-occipital joint.
      This alignment brings the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes into a straight line, facilitating easy visualization of the glottis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neck fully extended with chin elevated and no head support: Incorrect. Complete neck extension without flexion at the lower cervical spine misaligns the axes (oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal), making laryngoscopy more difficult.

 

Option C. Prone with head hanging down to align oral and laryngeal axes: Incorrect. Prone positioning is not used for laryngoscopy. It is unsuitable for airway procedures and may compromise ventilation.

 

Option D. Lateral position with head rotated to left to improve laryngeal exposure: Incorrect. Lateral positioning is not used for laryngeal exposure. It is more relevant for certain otologic or neurologic procedures but not for airway visualization.

 

Positioning Recap:

 

  • Patient supine
  • Pillow under occiput to elevate head (10–15 cm)
  • Neck flexed on thorax
  • Head extended at atlanto-occipital joint
    → This is the barking-dog position, optimal for direct laryngoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For direct laryngoscopy, the patient is positioned supine with neck flexed on thorax and head extended at the atlanto-occipital joint—known as the barking-dog position.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 422

choices.text: Tip, lingual surface, and laryngeal surface of epiglottis
Right and left middle meatus of the nasal cavity
Right and left vocal cords and their mobility

questions.text: During direct laryngoscopy, the surgeon systematically examines each part of the larynx and surrounding structures. Which of the following is not typically included in the routine sequence of structures examined during direct laryngoscopy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right and left middle meatus of the nasal cavity

 

The middle meatus is part of the nasal cavity and not examined during direct laryngoscopy. It is visualized using nasal endoscopy, not laryngoscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postcricoid region and pyriform sinuses: Correct. These are part of the hypopharyngeal region and are routinely examined during direct laryngoscopy, especially in cases of dysphagia, suspected malignancy, or globus sensation.

 

Option B. Tip, lingual surface, and laryngeal surface of epiglottis: Correct. The epiglottis is examined in detail from its anterior (lingual) and posterior (laryngeal) surfaces, including the tip, as it may be involved in tumors or inflammation.

 

Option D. Right and left vocal cords and their mobility: Correct. True vocal cords, including the anterior and posterior commissures, their ventricles, and mobility, are crucial to assess during direct laryngoscopy, especially in hoarseness or suspected vocal cord paralysis.

 

Structures routinely examined during direct laryngoscopy:

 

  • Base of tongue, valleculae,
  • Epiglottis (tip, lingual & laryngeal surfaces),
  • Aryepiglottic folds, arytenoids,
  • Pyriform sinuses, postcricoid region,
  • False cords, true vocal cords, ventricles,
  • Anterior and posterior commissures,
  • Subglottic area, and vocal cord mobility

 

Educational Objective:

 

Direct laryngoscopy systematically examines the supraglottic, glottic, and subglottic structures—but not nasal cavity components like the middle meatus.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 423

Perilymph fistula due to pressure changes

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoes direct laryngoscopy for biopsy of a laryngeal lesion. Postoperatively, he complains of sore throat and swelling. Which of the following is a recognized complication of direct laryngoscopy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laryngeal oedema leading to respiratory distress

 

Laryngeal oedema is a known complication of direct laryngoscopy, especially after manipulation, trauma, or biopsy. It can cause airway compromise, especially in patients with pre-existing laryngeal pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal septal perforation: Incorrect. This is a known complication of nasal surgeries or repeated nasal instrumentation, not direct laryngoscopy which involves the oropharyngeal and laryngeal structures.

 

Option C. Perilymph fistula due to pressure changes: Incorrect. This is associated with ear trauma or barotrauma during scuba diving or middle ear surgeries, not laryngoscopy.

 

Option D. Trigeminal neuralgia due to instrumentation: Incorrect. This is unrelated to laryngoscopy. The trigeminal nerve is not involved or affected by this procedure.

 

  • Other Common Complications of Direct Laryngoscopy:
    • Injury to lips and tongue if caught between teeth and laryngoscope blade
    • Dental injury, especially in elderly patients with loose teeth—teeth may get dislodged and aspirated
    • Bleeding, especially after biopsy or in vascular lesions
    • Laryngeal oedema, as mentioned, may cause stridor or airway obstruction postoperatively

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complications of direct laryngoscopy include injury to lips, teeth, bleeding, and laryngeal oedema, which can lead to airway obstruction.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 423

questions.text: A patient undergoes direct laryngoscopy with biopsy under general anesthesia. In the postoperative recovery room, which of the following is the most appropriate immediate step to prevent aspiration and monitor complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Keep the patient in coma position and monitor for laryngeal spasm and cyanosis

 

The coma position (lateral decubitus with head low) is ideal to prevent aspiration of blood or secretions. Also, close respiratory monitoring is required for signs of laryngeal edema, spasm, or cyanosis, especially after traumatic or repeated laryngoscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Place the patient flat in supine position with head extended: Incorrect. Supine position increases the risk of aspiration of blood or secretions, especially if bleeding occurs post-biopsy.

 

Option B. Observe only oxygen saturation and discharge if normal: Incorrect. Solely monitoring oxygen saturation may miss early signs of laryngeal spasm or edema. Full postoperative monitoring is essential.

 

Option D. Encourage oral feeding early to wash away blood from the oropharynx: Incorrect. Early oral feeding increases risk of aspiration, especially when laryngeal function and protective reflexes may still be compromised.

 

  • Key Components of Postoperative Care in Direct Laryngoscopy:
    • Coma position to prevent aspiration
    • Watch for laryngeal spasm, respiratory distress, or cyanosis
    • Be cautious of trauma-induced laryngeal edema after repeated attempts
    • Monitor for bleeding from biopsy site — patient may spit blood

 

Educational Objective:

 

After direct laryngoscopy, the patient should be kept in coma position and closely monitored for laryngeal spasm, cyanosis, or bleeding to prevent aspiration and airway compromise.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 422

questions.text: A 40-year-old male undergoes direct laryngoscopy under general anaesthesia for biopsy of a supraglottic lesion. Postoperatively, he complains of throat discomfort, and examination reveals mild bleeding and swelling. Which of the following is not a recognized complication of direct laryngoscopy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Facial nerve palsy due to prolonged jaw retraction

 

Facial nerve palsy is not a recognized complication of direct laryngoscopy. This complication may occur in jaw surgeries or prolonged head positioning, but not due to laryngoscope use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dislodgement of teeth into the pharynx: This is a known complication of direct laryngoscopy, especially in elderly patients or those with loose or prosthetic teeth. Dislodged teeth may fall into the pharynx and pose an aspiration risk.

 

Option B. Injury to lips or tongue caught between teeth and scope: This can occur if the lips or tongue are inadvertently nipped between the teeth and the laryngoscope blade, especially during insertion or withdrawal.

 

Option C. Laryngeal oedema leading to airway obstruction: Trauma to the larynx during laryngoscopy, especially if multiple attempts are made, can result in edema and postoperative respiratory distress. This is a well-documented risk.

 

  • Summary of Complications:
    • Lip and tongue injury if nipped between laryngoscope and teeth
    • Dental injury or dislodgement into the pharynx
    • Bleeding from trauma or biopsy site
    • Laryngeal oedema, especially after repeated instrumentation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common complications of direct laryngoscopy include injury to lips, teeth, bleeding, and laryngeal oedema, but not facial nerve palsy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 423

Flexible nasopharyngoscopy to assess vocal cord mobility

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with persistent wheezing and cough for over a month. Chest X-ray shows obstructive emphysema of the right lower lobe. The child had a choking episode two weeks ago while eating nuts. Which of the following is the most appropriate next diagnostic and therapeutic step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rigid bronchoscopy to visualize and remove a possible foreign body

 

  • Rigid bronchoscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic, particularly in children. It is indicated when:
    • Persistent cough or wheeze >4 weeks,
    • Chest X-ray shows obstructive emphysema,
    • There is suspicion of foreign body aspiration,
    • To collect bronchial secretions or to remove secretions or mucus plugs in comatosed/post-surgical patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High-resolution CT chest to rule out congenital anomaly: Incorrect. While CT may help in evaluating structural anomalies, the history of choking, persistent wheeze, and obstructive emphysema suggests a foreign body, which is best assessed by bronchoscopy, not CT.

 

Option C. Flexible nasopharyngoscopy to assess vocal cord mobility: Incorrect. While vocal cord palsy is an indication for bronchoscopy, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with airway foreign body, not vocal cord pathology.

 

Option D. Sputum AFB smear and empirical antitubercular therapy: Incorrect. There is no clinical or radiologic indication of TB here. Empirical ATT without microbiological evidence is not justified.

 

  • Key Indications of Rigid Bronchoscopy:
    • Diagnostic:
      • Persistent wheeze, haemoptysis, unexplained cough
      • X-ray signs: atelectasis, opacity, obstructive emphysema, hilar shadow
      • Evaluation of vocal cord palsy
      • Collection of secretions for microbiology/histopathology
    • Therapeutic:
      • Foreign body removal
      • Mucus plug/retained secretion removal in trauma or comatose patients

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigid bronchoscopy is indicated for persistent cough, obstructive emphysema, and suspected foreign body, and it allows both diagnosis and treatment.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 424

questions.text: A 55-year-old male undergoes direct laryngoscopy and biopsy for a suspicious glottic lesion. Post-procedure, he develops difficulty breathing, desaturation, and bleeding from the oral cavity. Which of the following is not a recognized complication of this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tension pneumothorax

 

This is not a typical complication of direct laryngoscopy. It is more commonly associated with trauma, barotrauma during ventilation, or certain thoracic procedures—not upper airway endoscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Injury to teeth and lips: Direct laryngoscopy requires the use of a rigid laryngoscope that can exert pressure on the lips or teeth, especially during difficult visualization, making this a known complication.

 

Option B. Laryngeal oedema: Trauma to the laryngeal mucosa, especially following repeated instrumentation or biopsy, can result in laryngeal oedema, which may cause airway compromise postoperatively.

 

Option C. Haemorrhage from biopsy site: This is a common complication when a biopsy is taken during direct laryngoscopy. It must be carefully monitored to prevent aspiration or airway obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complications of direct laryngoscopy include injury to teeth/lips, biopsy site hemorrhage, hypoxia, cardiac arrest, and laryngeal oedema, but not tension pneumothorax.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 424

questions.text: Which of the following statements best differentiates flexible bronchoscopy from rigid bronchoscopy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rigid bronchoscopy allows better control of ventilation especially in children

 

One of the key advantages of rigid bronchoscopy is better control of ventilation, particularly important in children or during foreign body removal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rigid bronchoscopy is preferred in children for foreign body removal due to better visualization of supraglottic area: While rigid bronchoscopy is indeed preferred for foreign body removal in children, the supraglottic area is actually difficult to evaluate with a rigid scope. This makes the first half of the statement incorrect.

 

Option B. Flexible bronchoscopy is better suited for massive hemoptysis due to scope size: Rigid bronchoscopy is preferred in massive hemoptysis because the tip can be used to tamponade bleeding areas, which is not possible with a flexible scope.

 

Option D. Flexible bronchoscopy permits larger biopsy specimens to be taken than rigid bronchoscopy: Rigid bronchoscopy can take larger tissue biopsies than flexible, which is limited to small samples.

questions.text: A 58-year-old ICU patient with persistent unexplained cough and secretions requires bronchoscopic evaluation. He has a recent mandibular fracture making rigid scope placement difficult. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Flexible fibreoptic bronchoscopy under topical anesthesia

 

Flexible fibreoptic bronchoscopy is ideal here. It provides magnification, illumination, and access to subsegmental bronchi. It is well-tolerated under topical anesthesia, useful in patients with neck/jaw injuries, and can even be performed at the bedside.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rigid bronchoscopy under general anesthesia: Incorrect. Rigid bronchoscopy requires neck and jaw mobility, which is compromised in this patient. Also, general anesthesia is riskier in critically ill patients.

 

Option C. Tracheostomy followed by rigid bronchoscopy: Incorrect. This is an unnecessarily invasive option when flexible bronchoscopy can easily be passed through the tracheostomy or endotracheal tube, if present.

 

Option D. Wait until fracture heals and then perform rigid bronchoscopy: Incorrect. Delaying diagnostic bronchoscopy in a symptomatic ICU patient risks further respiratory complications. Flexible bronchoscopy should be done immediately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flexible fibreoptic bronchoscopy is preferred in adults for diagnostic evaluation, especially in ICU settings or when rigid bronchoscopy is contraindicated due to jaw or neck injuries.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 425

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with high-grade fever, drooling, and stridor. A lateral soft tissue neck X-ray is ordered. Which of the following is the most appropriate reason for choosing this view in ENT practice?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It helps diagnose conditions like epiglottitis, foreign bodies, and retropharyngeal abscess

 

  • The lateral neck X-ray is an extremely useful view in ENT. It allows visualization of:
    • Base of tongue, vallecula, epiglottis (thumb sign in epiglottitis)
    • Laryngeal cartilages, vocal cords, subglottic space
    • Prevertebral and pretracheal soft tissues
    • Cervical spine

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It best evaluates otitis media with effusion: Incorrect. Otitis media with effusion is better assessed with otoscopy or tympanometry, not lateral neck X-ray.

 

Option B. It provides detailed visualization of paranasal sinuses: Incorrect. Waters view (occipitomental view) is typically used for paranasal sinus evaluation, not lateral neck view.

 

Option D. It is primarily used for orbital fracture assessment: Incorrect. Orbital fractures are assessed with CT orbit or occipitomental (Waters) view.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lateral soft tissue neck X-ray is a key radiological tool in ENT for diagnosing epiglottitis, foreign bodies, retropharyngeal abscess, tracheal compression, and evaluating laryngeal structures.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 434

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with sudden onset of cough and dysphagia after playing with coins. An X-ray is ordered to determine the location of a suspected foreign body. Which radiological view is most useful to differentiate between a laryngeal and an esophageal foreign body?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anteroposterior (AP) view of neck

 

  • The AP view of the neck is particularly useful for:
    • Differentiating between a foreign body in the larynx vs oesophagus (based on its position relative to the trachea)
    • Assessing compression or displacement of trachea by lateral neck masses such as thyroid swellings or lymphadenopathy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral skull view: Incorrect. This is used to visualize paranasal sinuses and skull bones but not ideal for larynx or esophageal foreign body.

 

Option B. Water’s view: Incorrect. Best suited for evaluation of maxillary sinuses and facial bones.

 

Option D. Caldwell view: Incorrect. It is used for frontal sinus evaluation and is not helpful for foreign body localization in the neck.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anteroposterior (AP) neck X-ray view helps differentiate laryngeal from esophageal foreign bodies and evaluate tracheal displacement by neck masses.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 434

questions.text: . A 10-year-old boy presents with chronic nasal obstruction and mouth breathing. A soft tissue lateral X-ray of the nasopharynx shows a soft tissue shadow compromising the nasopharyngeal airway, without a distinct air column between the mass and the posterior nasopharyngeal wall. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenoid hypertrophy

 

This is a common cause of nasopharyngeal airway obstruction in children. The mass arises from the posterosuperior wall of the nasopharynx and completely obliterates the air column, which distinguishes it from an antrochoanal polyp.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antrochoanal polyp: Incorrect. It arises from the maxillary sinus and extends into the nasopharynx. On X-ray, a column of air is typically seen between the mass and the posterior wall of the nasopharynx, helping to differentiate it from other masses like adenoids or angiofibroma.

 

Option B. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Incorrect. While this also arises from the posterosuperior wall of the nasopharynx, it is more vascular and common in adolescent males with epistaxis. The air column may be absent but other clinical signs must be present.

 

Option D. Nasal foreign body: Incorrect. Although a nasal foreign body may appear in the nasal cavity, it typically doesn't involve the nasopharyngeal soft tissue unless it migrates or causes secondary obstruction.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Adenoid hypertrophy appears as a soft tissue mass in the posterosuperior nasopharynx and causes complete obstruction of the nasopharyngeal airway without an air column on lateral X-ray.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 434

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is undergoing tracheostomy. The surgeon uses the instrument shown in the image to retract the thyroid isthmus and expose the trachea. Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blunt tracheal hook

 

The image shows a blunt tracheal hook, which is used to retract the thyroid isthmus upward or downward during tracheostomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngoscope blade: Incorrect. A laryngoscope blade is used for direct laryngoscopy, not for retracting structures during tracheostomy.

 

 

Option B. Sharp tracheal hook: Incorrect. The sharp tracheal hook has a pointed tip and is used to fix the trachea at the cricoid cartilage to prevent movement during incision, not for retraction.

 

 

Option D. Double hook retractor: Incorrect. Double hook retractors have two hooked prongs and are typically used for skin or soft tissue retraction, not for tracheostomy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blunt tracheal hook is used to retract the thyroid isthmus during tracheostomy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 459

questions.text: A surgeon is performing a tracheostomy and uses the instrument shown below to fix the trachea at the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. The aim is to stabilize the trachea and prevent movement during incision. Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sharp tracheal hook

 

The image shows a sharp tracheal hook, used to fix the trachea at the cricoid cartilage during tracheostomy, stabilizing it to prevent movement during respiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blunt tracheal hook: Incorrect. The blunt hook is used to retract the thyroid isthmus during tracheostomy, not to fix the trachea.

 

 

Option B. Cricoid hook: Incorrect. This is not a standard term used for this instrument. It refers to a sharp tracheal hook when applied at the cricoid cartilage.

 

Option D. Thyroid retractor: Incorrect. Thyroid retractors are broader instruments used to retract tissues during thyroidectomy, not pointed hooks like the one shown.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sharp tracheal hook is used to fix the trachea at the cricoid cartilage during tracheostomy to prevent its movement.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 459

questions.text: A 55-year-old male is undergoing an emergency tracheostomy. After making an incision in the trachea, the surgeon uses the instrument shown below to facilitate insertion of the tracheostomy tube by keeping the tracheal edges apart. Identify this instrument:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tracheal dilator

 

This instrument is specifically designed to separate the tracheal walls and keep the opening patent for easy insertion of a tracheostomy tube.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheal hook: Incorrect. A tracheal hook is used to retract soft tissues or fix the trachea (blunt or sharp), not to dilate the tracheal opening.

 

 

Option C. Tonsil dissector: Incorrect. Used in tonsillectomy procedures to dissect the tonsil from its bed, not in tracheostomy.

 

 

Option D. Laryngoscope blade: Incorrect. Used to visualize the larynx during intubation, not for surgical airway access.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A tracheal dilator is used during tracheostomy to keep the tracheal incision open for easy tube insertion.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 459

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought with inspiratory stridor and hoarseness. Direct laryngoscopy is planned under general anesthesia. Identify the instrument shown in the image that is used for this purpose:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laryngoscope

 

This is a direct laryngoscope, used to visualize the larynx and surrounding structures for diagnosis or foreign body removal, especially in children. It can also have light sources (bulb or cold light cable).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Boyle-Davis mouth gag: Incorrect. This is used during tonsillectomy to keep the mouth open and tongue depressed, not for viewing the larynx.

 

 

Option C. Tonsil holding forceps: Incorrect. These are used to hold and retract the tonsil during tonsillectomy.

 

 

Option D. Bronchoscope: Incorrect. Bronchoscope is used to visualize tracheobronchial tree, not the larynx directly.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngoscope is used for direct visualization of the larynx during diagnostic or therapeutic procedures like biopsy or foreign body removal.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 459

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with dysphagia and drooling of saliva. A coin was seen in the upper esophagus on X-ray. The following instrument is used for its removal under general anesthesia. Identify the instrument shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oesophagoscope

 

The instrument shown is a Negus oesophagoscope with twin proximal lighting. It is used for diagnostic or therapeutic oesophagoscopy (e.g., foreign body removal, biopsy). It is a rigid instrument with a handle that indicates the bevel’s orientation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngoscope: Incorrect. Used for direct visualization of the larynx, not the esophagus.

 

 

Option B. Bronchoscope: Incorrect. Used to visualize the tracheobronchial tree, not the esophagus.

 

 

Option D. Rigid endoscope: Correct. Although technically the oesophagoscope is a type of rigid endoscope, this option is too vague for the specific image shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Negus oesophagoscope is a rigid endoscopic instrument used for diagnostic and therapeutic procedures in the esophagus, especially for foreign body removal.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 459

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below and select the correct statement regarding its use:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bronchoscope; has fenestrations to ventilate contralateral lung

 

  • Instrument Identified: Rigid bronchoscope
  • Features:
    • Has openings (fenestrations) near the distal end, which allow ventilation of contralateral lung or side bronchi
    • Bevelled distal tip aids in smooth passage between vocal cords
    • Size of bronchoscope varies with age (refer Table A1 from standard ENT texts)
  • Common Uses: Diagnostic and therapeutic bronchoscopy including foreign body removal, biopsy, and ventilation assessment

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oesophagoscope: Used for examining esophagus; doesn’t have side fenestrations and is not meant for vocal cord assessment.

 

 

Option C. Laryngoscope: Used for direct laryngoscopy, doesn’t have a long tubular body or fenestrations.

 

 

Option D. Nasopharyngoscope: A flexible fiberoptic scope, not rigid or bevelled like the image shown.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigid bronchoscope has distal fenestrations to aid ventilation and a bevelled tip to ease passage between vocal cords.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 459

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is planned for an elective tracheostomy due to prolonged intubation. What is the most appropriate inner diameter of the tracheostomy tube to be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5.5 mm

 

According to standard guidelines, for a 6–9 years old child, the recommended inner diameter of tracheostomy tube is 5.5 mm.

 

Correct size for 6–9 years

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 4.0 mm: Used in 6–18-month-olds

 

Option B. 4.5 mm: Used in 18 months to 3 years

 

Option D. 6.0 mm: Suitable for 9–12 years

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recommended inner diameter of tracheostomy tube for a 6–9-year-old child is 5.5 mm.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 460

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is scheduled for rigid bronchoscopy due to suspected foreign body aspiration. What is the most appropriate size of the bronchoscope tube for this age group?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4.5 mm

 

  • Based on age-specific sizing:
    • Preterm–1 month: 2.5 mm
    • 1–6 months: 3.0 mm
    • 6–18 months: 3.5 mm
    • 18 months to 3 years: 4.0 mm
    • 3–6 years: 4.5 mm (Correct choice for a 3-year-old child)
    • 6–9 years: 5.0 mm
    • Appropriate for 3–6 years age group

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3.5 mm: For infants aged 6–18 months

 

Option B. 4.0 mm: For toddlers up to 3 years

 

Option D. 5.0 mm: Suitable for children aged 6–9 years

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate bronchoscope size for children aged 3–6 years is 4.5 mm.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 460
