questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below and choose the correct statement about its design or function:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The inner tube is longer and has a central hole to allow breathing from the larynx

 

The image shows Fuller’s tracheostomy tube, a metallic double-lumen tracheostomy tube.

 

Key features:

 

  • It has two components: an outer tube (with two flexible blades for insertion) and an inner tube.
  • The inner tube is slightly longer than the outer one and has a central hole, which allows air passage from the larynx, even if the outer opening is blocked.
  • This makes it useful in emergencies or partial obstructions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It consists of a single tube with a fenestration for phonation: Single tube with fenestration describes a fenestrated cuffed tube, not Fuller’s.

 

Option B. The inner tube is shorter and prevents aspiration: The inner tube is longer, not shorter; its function is not to prevent aspiration but to maintain patency.

 

Option C. The outer tube has flexible flanges that make insertion easier: The outer tube has two blades, not flexible flanges.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fuller’s tracheostomy tube has a longer inner tube with a central hole to allow breathing via the larynx in case the external opening is blocked.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 462

choices.text: The outer tube is split for easy insertion into the trachea
The obturator is used during tube insertion and removed immediately afterward
The inner tube is permanently fixed to the outer tube
The tube allows phonation through a central fenestration

questions.text: Identify the type of tracheostomy tube shown below and select the correct statement regarding its structure:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The obturator is used during tube insertion and removed immediately afterward

 

The image shows Jackson’s tracheostomy tube, which consists of three parts:

 

  • Outer tube – non-split, provides the main structural support
  • Inner tube – locks into the outer tube and can be removed for cleaning
  • Obturator (Pilot) – used to guide the outer tube during insertion, and is removed once the tube is in place

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The outer tube is split for easy insertion into the trachea: Outer tube in Jackson’s tube is not split (unlike Fuller’s tube)

 

Option C. The inner tube is permanently fixed to the outer tube: Inner tube is removable and not permanently fixed

 

Option D. The tube allows phonation through a central fenestration Jackson’s tube is not fenestrated, hence not meant for phonation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jackson’s tracheostomy tube has a non-split outer tube, a lockable inner tube, and an obturator used only during insertion.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 462

choices.text: The cuff prevents ventilator air-leak but increases the risk of aspiration
The cuff must always remain inflated to prevent tracheal collapse
The tube is contraindicated in patients on mechanical ventilation
The cuff should be deflated periodically to prevent tracheal damage

questions.text: Identify the type of tracheostomy tube shown and choose the correct statement regarding its use:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The cuff should be deflated periodically to prevent tracheal damage

 

  • The image shows a cuffed tracheostomy tube, which includes an inflatable balloon (cuff) that seals the tracheal lumen.
  • It prevents aspiration of pharyngeal secretions and also avoids air leak during mechanical ventilation.
  • However, continuous cuff pressure on the tracheal wall can lead to tracheal mucosal damage or cartilage necrosis, hence intermittent deflation (every 2 hours for 5 minutes) is recommended.
  • Newer designs may include double cuffs to alternate pressure sites and reduce localized injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The cuff prevents ventilator air-leak but increases the risk of aspiration: Cuff actually prevents aspiration.

 

Option B. The cuff must always remain inflated to prevent tracheal collapse: Continuous inflation is harmful, not mandatory.

 

Option C. The tube is contraindicated in patients on mechanical ventilation: It is actually indicated in ventilated patients to prevent air-leak.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cuffed tracheostomy tubes are used to prevent aspiration and air leak in ventilated or unconscious patients, but the cuff must be deflated intermittently to prevent tracheal injury.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 462

choices.text: It has a cuff but no channel for suction
It allows direct suctioning of secretions collected above the cuff
Suction should be done after cuff deflation to prevent tube damage
It cannot be used in unconscious or ventilated patients

questions.text: Identify the tracheostomy tube shown and select the correct statement about its function:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It allows direct suctioning of secretions collected above the cuff

 

  • This image shows a Cuffed Suction-Aid Tracheostomy Tube, an advanced version of the standard cuffed tracheostomy tube.
  • It has:
    • A cuff to prevent aspiration and air leak.
    • An additional suction port/tube that extends above the cuff, allowing removal of secretions that accumulate above the cuff, thus preventing aspiration when cuff is deflated.
  • Suctioning should always be done before cuff deflation to avoid aspiration of pharyngeal secretions into the tracheobronchial tree.
  • These tubes are especially useful in ICU settings for patients who are unconscious or ventilator-dependent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It has a cuff but no channel for suction: The suction channel is the key feature distinguishing this tube.

 

Option C. Suction should be done after cuff deflation to prevent tube damage: Suction must be done before, not after cuff deflation.

 

Option D. It cannot be used in unconscious or ventilated patients: It is ideally suited for unconscious/ventilated patients at risk of aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cuffed suction-aid tracheostomy tubes allow suctioning of secretions above the cuff and must be suctioned before deflating the cuff to prevent aspiration.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 462

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is scheduled for elective intubation under general anesthesia. According to standard recommendations, what is the appropriate internal diameter (ID) of the endotracheal tube and its approximate length?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ID = 5.0 mm; Length = 15.0 cm

 

To calculate the internal diameter (ID) of an endotracheal tube in a child:

 

 

For a 4-year-old:

 

  • Tube size=4/4+4=1+4=5.0 mm
  • To estimate the length of the tube:
  • Length (cm)=Tube size×3=5×3=15 cm
  • Also, a quick bedside estimate is to compare the size of the tube with the child’s little finger.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 4.5 mm and 13.5 cm: Underestimates both ID and length.

 

Option C. 5.5 mm and 16.5 cm: Overestimates for a 4-year-old.

 

Option D. 6.0 mm and 18.0 cm: Suitable for older children (approx. 8 years).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In children, the internal diameter of the endotracheal tube (in mm) = (Age in years ÷ 4) + 4, and the length (in cm) ≈ 3 × tube size.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 463

choices.text: French gauge directly indicates the inner diameter of the tracheostomy tube in mm
A Jackson’s tube of size 36 FG has an approximate inner diameter of 12 mm
Adult tracheostomy tubes typically have an inner diameter between 6 mm and 10 mm
Higher the number of the tracheostomy tube, smaller is its diameter

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the selection of tracheostomy tube size in adults?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adult tracheostomy tubes typically have an inner diameter between 6 mm and 10 mm

 

  • Tube size selection in adults is based on the inner diameter (ID) of the tracheostomy tube.
  • Adult tube sizes range from 6 to 9 or 10 mm ID.
  • French Gauge (FG) refers to outer diameter and is calculated as:

  • So, a tube with 36 FG has an outer diameter of ~12 mm, not inner.
  • Jackson’s and Negus tracheostomy tubes often use FG markings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. French gauge directly indicates the inner diameter of the tracheostomy tube in mm: False. FG corresponds to outer, not inner, diameter.

 

Option B. A Jackson’s tube of size 36 FG has an approximate inner diameter of 12 mm: Incorrect. 36 FG = 12 mm outer, not inner, diameter.

 

Option D. Higher the number of the tracheostomy tube, smaller is its diameter: Opposite. Larger number = larger diameter, not smaller.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In adults, tracheostomy tube size is chosen by inner diameter (typically 6–10 mm), while French gauge indicates the outer diameter (FG = OD × 3.14).

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 463

choices.text: LMA provides complete protection against aspiration of gastric secretions
LMA is ideal for patients with trismus or glottic obstruction
LMA can assist in intubation with a stylet or a small endotracheal tube
LMA is placed blindly into the trachea similar to endotracheal intubation

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA) is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LMA can assist in intubation with a stylet or a small endotracheal tube

 

 

  • LMA is a supraglottic airway device that sits over the laryngeal inlet.
  • It is used when face mask ventilation is ineffective or intubation is difficult.
  • The cuff is deflated before insertion and then inflated after positioning.
  • It allows for:
    • Direct intubation with small ETTs (<6 mm ID),
    • Or stylet insertion followed by railroading the tube.
    • Also allows passage of a flexible bronchoscope for fiberoptic airway assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LMA provides complete protection against aspiration of gastric secretions: False. LMA does not fully protect against gastric aspiration.

 

Option B. LMA is ideal for patients with trismus or glottic obstruction: Contraindicated – LMA is not suitable for patients with glottic/subglottic obstruction or trismus.

 

Option D. LMA is placed blindly into the trachea similar to endotracheal intubation: Incorrect. LMA is not inserted into the trachea but placed over the supraglottic region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal Mask Airway is a supraglottic device used when intubation is difficult; it does not prevent aspiration and is contraindicated in glottic obstruction or trismus.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 464

choices.text: Perform indirect laryngoscopy to confirm diagnosis
Arrange for airway management and proceed to intubation
Order soft tissue neck X-ray lateral view immediately

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with complaints of sudden high-grade fever, difficulty breathing, and drooling of saliva. The child is sitting leaning forward and refuses to lie down. Inspiratory stridor is noted. On examination, the cry is normal. What is the most appropriate immediate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arrange for airway management and proceed to intubation

 

  • This is a classical case of Acute Epiglottitis, most commonly caused by Haemophilus influenzae type B in children aged 2–7 years. It presents as:
    • Sudden high-grade fever
    • Inspiratory stridor
    • Drooling of saliva, dysphagia
    • Tripod sign: child prefers to sit leaning forward
    • Normal cry, unlike laryngotracheobronchitis (croup)
    • Red, swollen epiglottis on laryngoscopy (not routinely attempted due to risk of laryngospasm)

 

 

  • Management requires immediate airway protection:
    • Endotracheal intubation if signs of respiratory distress
    • Tracheostomy if prolonged intubation (>72 hrs) is anticipated
    • IV antibiotics, steroids, humidified oxygen, and fluids

 

The first and most urgent step is securing the airway. Intubation under controlled conditions is life-saving.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perform indirect laryngoscopy to confirm diagnosis: Dangerous in acute epiglottitis as it may precipitate complete airway obstruction due to laryngospasm.

 

Option B. Administer oral antibiotics and discharge: Inappropriate. The child is in respiratory distress. Needs hospital admission and airway protection.

 

Option D. Order soft tissue neck X-ray lateral view immediately: Though the thumb sign is diagnostic, X-ray should never delay airway management in a child in distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute epiglottitis in children is a medical emergency requiring urgent airway management before diagnostic procedures.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 289

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with complaints of low-grade fever, barking cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor. The symptoms began gradually over the past 2 days. On examination, he has intercostal retractions and mild respiratory distress. A soft tissue neck X-ray (AP view) shows subglottic narrowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

 

  • This child presents with classic signs of Croup, also known as Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis, which commonly affects children aged 6 months to 3 years, more often in males.
  • Etiology: Most common viruses include Parainfluenza types I & II, and also Influenza A & B, Measles virus, Adenovirus, and RSV.
  • Pathophysiology: Swelling of the subglottic loose areolar tissue along with thick secretions causes airway narrowing and stridor.
  • Symptoms: Gradual onset of fever, hoarseness, barking (croupy) cough, inspiratory stridor, and intercostal retractions.
  • X-ray finding: Steeple sign on AP neck X-ray, indicating subglottic narrowing.
  • Treatment: Includes humidified oxygen, IV fluids, steroids, and tracheostomy if prolonged intubation is needed.

 

The clinical picture and steeple sign confirm the diagnosis of Croup.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute epiglottitis: Sudden onset, drooling, severe dysphagia, and tripod posture are characteristic—not barking cough or gradual onset.

 

 

Option B. Foreign body aspiration: More likely to cause sudden onset choking, unilateral decreased breath sounds, and often no fever or cough unless complicated.

 

Option D. Retropharyngeal abscess: Typically presents with neck stiffness, torticollis, dysphagia, and bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall. No barking cough or steeple sign.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Croup presents with barking cough, gradual onset stridor, and steeple sign on X-ray, most commonly due to Parainfluenza virus in children aged 6 months to 3 years.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 290

choices.text: Immediate surgical debridement of the membrane
Start broad-spectrum antibiotics and wait for culture
Administer diphtheria antitoxin and begin antibiotics
Perform emergency tracheostomy without medical therapy

questions.text: A 4-year-old unvaccinated child is brought to the emergency department with fever, sore throat, and difficulty breathing. On examination, a grayish-white membrane is seen over the pharynx which bleeds when an attempt is made to remove it. The child has swollen neck with prominent cervical lymph nodes ("bull neck" appearance). What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer diphtheria antitoxin and begin antibiotics

 

  • This case is classic for laryngeal diphtheria, caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Hallmark features include:
    • Grayish-white pseudomembrane that bleeds on removal
    • Cervical lymphadenopathy causing bull neck appearance
    • Can cause airway obstruction due to laryngeal involvement
    • Treatment requires:
    • Diphtheria antitoxin (neutralizes the circulating toxin; critical to administer early)
    • Antibiotics (penicillin or erythromycin)
    • Airway maintenance (may require intubation or tracheostomy if respiratory compromise develops)

 

This is the standard and most urgent first step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate surgical debridement of the membrane: Contraindicated as it may cause bleeding and toxin release.

 

Option B. Start broad-spectrum antibiotics and wait for culture: Delays life-saving antitoxin therapy; toxin damage is time-dependent.

 

Option D. Perform emergency tracheostomy without medical therapy: Airway support may be required in severe cases, but not without concurrent medical therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal diphtheria is treated urgently with diphtheria antitoxin, antibiotics, and airway support if needed.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 290

choices.text: Direct laryngoscopy and biopsy of the lesion
Microlaryngeal surgery to excise the ulcer

questions.text: A 38-year-old male with known pulmonary tuberculosis presents with hoarseness of voice and pain during speaking. He also complains of easy voice fatigue. On laryngoscopic examination, the posterior part of the vocal cords and arytenoids show ulceration with a “mouse-nibbled” appearance. There is also diffuse thickening of the epiglottis resembling a turban. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Direct laryngoscopy and biopsy of the lesion

 

  • This patient presents with classical findings of laryngeal tuberculosis, which is usually secondary to pulmonary TB. The organism reaches the larynx via infected secretions from the lungs.
  • Key features:
    • Most commonly involves the posterior part of the larynx (arytenoids) initially
    • Later spreads to inferior surface of vocal cords
    • Symptoms include hoarseness, painful phonation, and voice fatigue
    • Mouse-nibbled ulcers on vocal cords and turban epiglottis are characteristic laryngoscopic findings
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by:
    • Biopsy of the lesion via direct laryngoscopy (gold standard)
  • Treatment is:
    • Standard antitubercular therapy (ATT) for 6 months

 

Biopsy confirms the diagnosis before starting ATT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start empirical antifungal therapy: Not appropriate. Fungal infections may present similarly but biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Option C. Microlaryngeal surgery to excise the ulcer: Not indicated. This is an infectious condition treated medically.

 

Option D. Immediate tracheostomy to prevent aspiration: Not needed unless airway obstruction is imminent, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal tuberculosis presents with painful phonation and a “mouse-nibbled” vocal cord appearance; diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy via direct laryngoscopy and treated with ATT.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 291

choices.text: Vocal cords are wider in infants
Epiglottis is positioned below the soft palate
Larynx lies at the level of C1–C2 vertebrae
Trachea is more rigid in infants

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought for routine examination. The mother asks how the baby is able to suckle milk and breathe at the same time without choking. The pediatrician explains that this is due to the unique anatomical positioning of the larynx in infants. Which of the following best explains this ability?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Larynx lies at the level of C1–C2 vertebrae

 

  • In infants, the larynx is positioned higher in the neck (at the level of C1–C2), compared to C4–C5 in adults. This higher position allows:
  • The epiglottis to approximate the soft palate, forming a nasopharyngeal channel behind it.
  • Air to pass from the nasal cavity directly to the larynx and trachea, allowing simultaneous breathing during suckling.
  • Milk passes laterally from the sides of the epiglottis into the esophagus, avoiding the airway.
  • This anatomical adaptation is essential in neonates and infants to facilitate safe feeding while maintaining airway patency.

 

This high position facilitates the ability to suckle and breathe simultaneously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal cords are wider in infants: Incorrect. In fact, the infant airway is narrower, especially at the subglottis.

 

Option B. Epiglottis is positioned below the soft palate: Incorrect. The epiglottis touches the soft palate (not below), enabling the formation of the air channel.

 

Option D. Trachea is more rigid in infants: Incorrect. The infant trachea is more compliant and collapsible, not more rigid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The high-lying larynx at the C1–C2 level in infants allows the epiglottis to contact the soft palate, enabling simultaneous breathing and suckling.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 285

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought by his parents with a history of noisy breathing since birth. The stridor is inspiratory, worsens when the baby cries, and improves when placed in a prone position. On flexible laryngoscopy, a floppy epiglottis and redundant arytenoid mucosa are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laryngomalacia

 

  • Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital anomaly of the larynx and the most common cause of stridor in infants.
  • It results from flaccidity of the supraglottic structures (epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, arytenoids), which collapse inward during inspiration, leading to inspiratory stridor.
  • Stridor worsens when the child cries or lies supine and improves in prone position.
  • Omega-shaped epiglottis, floppy AEF, and bulky arytenoids are classical findings.
  • Most cases resolve by 2 years of age as the cartilages mature and stiffen.
  • Surgery (supraglottoplasty) or tracheostomy is reserved for severe cases or persistence beyond 2 years.

 

Classical history of inspiratory stridor, worsening on crying, improving when prone, and findings on laryngoscopy confirm this.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheomalacia: Incorrect. Tracheomalacia causes expiratory stridor due to tracheal wall collapse, not inspiratory stridor.

 

Option B. Subglottic stenosis: Incorrect. This causes biphasic stridor and may follow intubation trauma.

 

 

Option D. Vocal cord paralysis: Incorrect. It typically causes biphasic stridor and weak cry, not related to position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of inspiratory stridor in infants, characterized by supraglottic flaccidity that improves in prone position.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 295

questions.text: A 3-week-old neonate presents with weak cry and signs of mild respiratory distress. There is no history of intubation. Flexible laryngoscopy reveals a thin membranous structure between the vocal cords. What is the most likely underlying cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laryngeal web

 

  • Laryngeal web is a congenital anomaly caused by incomplete recanalization of the larynx during embryogenesis.
  • This leads to formation of a thin membrane (web) typically between the vocal cords.
  • Symptoms include weak cry, airway obstruction, and respiratory distress in newborns.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by laryngoscopy, which reveals a web-like structure across the glottis.
  • Treatment is surgical excision using microlaryngeal instruments or CO₂ laser to restore airway patency and improve voice quality.

 

 

It presents with weak cry and membranous fusion of vocal cords due to incomplete laryngeal recanalization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal cord paralysis: Incorrect. While this can present with weak cry and stridor, laryngoscopy would show a cord in abducted or paramedian position—not a membranous web.

 

Option B. Subglottic stenosis: Incorrect. This affects the area below the vocal cords and presents with biphasic stridor and often history of intubation.

 

 

Option D. Laryngomalacia: Incorrect. It presents with inspiratory stridor that worsens on crying, not with a weak cry and web formation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal web results from incomplete laryngeal recanalization and presents with weak cry and airway obstruction in neonates, requiring surgical excision.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 295

choices.text: Congenital vocal cord paralysis due to Arnold-Chiari malformation

questions.text: A 2-week-old newborn presents with inspiratory stridor and weak cry since birth. There is no history of intubation. Laryngoscopy reveals immobile vocal cords in the paramedian position. MRI brain shows hindbrain herniation with hydrocephalus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Congenital vocal cord paralysis due to Arnold-Chiari malformation

 

  • Congenital vocal cord paralysis is a significant cause of neonatal stridor and respiratory distress.
  • It can be neurological in origin, most notably due to Arnold-Chiari malformation—a congenital brain malformation associated with hydrocephalus and hindbrain herniation.
  • Another etiology includes birth trauma (e.g., breech or forceps delivery) causing recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury.
  • In cases with severe airway obstruction, tracheostomy may be required to secure the airway.

 

It is the most common CNS anomaly causing congenital VC paralysis, usually associated with hydrocephalus and hindbrain herniation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngomalacia: Incorrect. Though it's the most common cause of stridor in infants, it typically presents with a floppy supraglottis and omega-shaped epiglottis, not vocal cord immobility.

 

 

Option C. Subglottic stenosis: Incorrect. This causes fixed airway obstruction below the cords. It does not cause vocal cord immobility or weak cry from birth.

 

 

Option D. Vocal cord granuloma: Incorrect. This is usually acquired after intubation or due to reflux and is rare in neonates.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arnold-Chiari malformation is the most common CNS anomaly causing congenital vocal cord paralysis, presenting with stridor and weak cry in neonates.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 295

choices.text: Immediate tracheostomy and long-term T-tube placement

questions.text: A 2-month-old full-term infant presents with biphasic stridor and respiratory distress since birth. Flexible laryngoscopy shows normal supraglottic and glottic structures. Subglottic airway diameter is measured as 3.5 mm. CT neck confirms thickened cricoid cartilage. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endoscopic dilatation or laser excision

 

  • Congenital subglottic stenosis is the third most common congenital laryngeal anomaly and results from abnormal thickening of the cricoid cartilage.
  • Diagnostic criterion: Subglottic diameter < 4 mm in full-term neonates, < 3 mm in preterm.
  • The degree of stenosis is graded using the Cotton-Meyer classification:
    • Grade I: <50% obstruction
    • Grade II: 51–70%
    • Grade III: 71–99%
    • Grade IV: complete (100%)

 

 

  • For Grade I and II, conservative management or endoscopic treatment (dilatation or laser excision) is typically effective.
  • Higher grades (III/IV) may require tracheostomy and surgical reconstruction later.

 

Appropriate for Grade I or II subglottic stenosis as first-line treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngotracheal reconstruction with cartilage graft: Incorrect. This is reserved for higher grade stenosis (Grade III or IV), not for mild to moderate narrowing.

 

Option B. Conservative observation only: Incorrect. This infant is symptomatic with biphasic stridor and confirmed Grade II stenosis. Active intervention is needed.

 

Option D. Immediate tracheostomy and long-term T-tube placement: Incorrect. Tracheostomy is needed for severe stenosis (Grade III or IV), not in moderate narrowing where endoscopic methods are successful.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grade I and II congenital subglottic stenosis are treated with endoscopic dilatation or laser excision; higher grades may need tracheostomy and laryngotracheal reconstruction.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 295

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with progressive hoarseness and intermittent stridor for the past few months. There is no history of fever or choking. He was born by vaginal delivery. On flexible laryngoscopy, multiple wart-like lesions are seen over the true vocal cords. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Juvenile laryngeal papillomatosis

 

  • Juvenile laryngeal papillomatosis is the most common benign laryngeal tumor in children.

 

 

  • Caused by HPV types 6 & 11 (type 11 more aggressive).
  • Transmission is typically perinatal via vaginal delivery.
  • Glottis is the most common site, followed by supraglottis and subglottis.
  • Presents between 3–5 years with hoarseness, dysphonia, and sometimes stridor.
  • Diagnosis is made via flexible laryngoscopy and confirmed with direct laryngoscopic biopsy.
  • Treatment includes microlaryngeal excision (laser or debrider).
  • Recurrences are common.
  • Adjuvant therapies may include interferon-α2a, intralesional cidofovir, or retinoic acid.

 

Classic presentation with hoarseness, wart-like lesions, history of vaginal delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital subglottic stenosis: Presents with stridor from birth or early infancy; hoarseness is not a typical feature.

 

 

Option B. Laryngeal web: Causes weak cry or airway obstruction in neonates; not typically wart-like lesions on cords.

 

 

Option D. Vocal cord nodules: Occur in older children/adults who use voice excessively (e.g., teachers, singers), not toddlers.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile laryngeal papillomatosis presents with hoarseness and stridor in young children due to HPV 6/11 and is managed with microlaryngeal surgery.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 305

choices.text: Glottic carcinoma – early change in voice

questions.text: A 62-year-old chronic smoker presents with persistent hoarseness of voice for the past 3 months. He denies any dysphagia, odynophagia, or neck swelling. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals a suspicious lesion over the true vocal cords. What is the most likely diagnosis and reason for early presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glottic carcinoma – early change in voice

 

  • Glottic carcinoma arises from the true vocal cords.
  • Change in voice (hoarseness) is often the earliest and most prominent symptom, leading to early detection.
  • It has limited lymphatic supply, hence low nodal metastasis and good prognosis.
  • Biopsy confirms diagnosis; CT/MRI helps assess extent and plan treatment.

 

Involvement of vocal cords leads to hoarseness, prompting early medical attention and diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supraglottic carcinoma – early nodal spread: Supraglottic cancers have rich lymphatics and present late, often with dysphagia, pain, or referred otalgia.

 

 

Option C. Subglottic carcinoma – early stridor: Subglottic tumors present late with stridor once significant airway obstruction occurs.

 

 

Option D. Hypopharyngeal carcinoma – referred otalgia: Referred otalgia can occur, but hoarseness is not an early symptom, and diagnosis is usually delayed.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glottic carcinoma presents early with hoarseness due to vocal cord involvement and has a good prognosis due to low lymphatic spread.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 307

choices.text: T4aN0M0 – Total laryngectomy with postoperative radiotherapy

questions.text: A 59-year-old male chronic smoker presents with hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Indirect laryngoscopy shows a mass involving the supraglottis and extending into the glottis. Vocal cord movement is impaired but not fixed. No lymphadenopathy is noted on clinical examination or imaging. What is the TNM stage, and what is the most appropriate treatment at this point?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T2N0M0 – Radiotherapy or conservative surgery

 

  • The tumor involves more than one subsite (supraglottis + glottis) and has impaired cord mobility → T2
  • No nodes clinically or radiologically → N0
  • No evidence of metastasis → M0
  • So, TNM = T2N0M0 → Stage II
    Stage II laryngeal cancer is managed with radiotherapy as first-line treatment. If radiotherapy fails, conservation surgery (partial laryngectomy) is considered.

 

Involves adjacent subsites and impaired cord mobility; this matches Stage II.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T1N0M0 – Radiotherapy alone: Incorrect. T1 would involve a single subsite only, without impaired mobility.

 

Option C. T3N0M0 – Chemoradiotherapy: T3 implies fixed vocal cords or pre-epiglottic space involvement, which is not seen here.

 

Option D. T4aN0M0 – Total laryngectomy with postoperative radiotherapy: T4a includes cartilage invasion or extension beyond the larynx, not described in this case.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

T2N0M0 laryngeal cancers involve adjacent subsites with impaired vocal cord mobility and are best treated initially with radiotherapy or conservation surgery.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 307

questions.text: A 62-year-old male chronic smoker presents with persistent hoarseness and recent onset of odynophagia. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals a mass confined to the glottis with a fixed left vocal cord. CT scan shows no cartilage invasion or lymphadenopathy. No distant metastases are identified. What is the most appropriate management at this stage?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chemoradiotherapy

 

  • The lesion is confined to the glottis but with a fixed vocal cord, which classifies it as T3.
  • No nodal involvement → N0, no metastasis → M0
  • Hence, TNM stage: T3N0M0 → Stage III
  • Stage III laryngeal carcinoma is best treated with concurrent chemoradiotherapy, aiming for organ preservation and control of local disease.

 

First-line for T3N0M0 laryngeal cancer (Stage III) with the goal of organ preservation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiotherapy alone: Insufficient for T3 lesions. Voice preservation with chemo-RT is preferred due to cord fixation.

 

Option C. Total laryngectomy with radiotherapy: Reserved for more advanced lesions (T4a) or failed chemo-RT.

 

Option D. Palliative radiotherapy: Only indicated in Stage IVb or IVc with poor prognosis (e.g., M1 or N3).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fixed vocal cord without nodal involvement (T3N0M0) in laryngeal cancer is managed with concurrent chemoradiotherapy for organ preservation.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 307

questions.text: A 58-year-old male underwent total laryngectomy for advanced laryngeal carcinoma. Postoperatively, he presents with an inability to speak. Which of the following is the most effective long-term method for voice rehabilitation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tracheo-esophageal speech with voice prosthesis

 

  • After total laryngectomy, the larynx and vocal cords are removed, leading to permanent loss of natural voice. Rehabilitation options include:
    • Tracheo-esophageal speech is the most effective and natural-sounding method. A voice prosthesis like Blom-Singer, Provox, or Groningen valve is inserted between trachea and esophagus, allowing pulmonary air to vibrate the pharyngo-esophageal segment and produce voice.

 

 

Most effective and widely used method. Produces near-natural voice and easy to learn.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrolarynx: Provides robotic, artificial-sounding voice. Useful temporarily, but not the most effective for long-term rehabilitation.

 

 

Option B. Esophageal speech: Involves swallowing and releasing air to vibrate pharyngo-esophageal segment. Takes long time to learn and voice quality is poor.

 

Option D. Writing communication with notepad: Not a rehabilitative method, only a temporary measure. Doesn't restore functional voice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheo-esophageal speech using a voice prosthesis (e.g., Blom-Singer valve) is the most effective method for voice rehabilitation after total laryngectomy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 307

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with carcinoma of the larynx undergoes total laryngectomy. A permanent tracheostomy is created intraoperatively. Which of the following statements regarding tracheostomy is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vertical skin incision is preferred in emergency tracheostomy

 

Emergency tracheostomy is done when airway compromise occurs acutely. To minimize time, a vertical incision is preferred to rapidly access the trachea.

 

Quick access is needed, and vertical incisions allow rapid dissection and exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheostomy increases the anatomical dead space and airway resistance: Incorrect. It reduces dead space by approximately 50%, improving ventilatory efficiency.

 

Option B. Tracheostomy is usually done at the level of the first tracheal ring in elective procedures: Incorrect. Elective tracheostomies are commonly done at 2nd–3rd tracheal rings. First ring is avoided to prevent subglottic stenosis.

 

Option D. Subglottic stenosis is an indication for tracheostomy: Incorrect. Subglottic stenosis is a complication, not an indication, of tracheostomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vertical skin incision is used in emergency tracheostomy to provide quick access to the trachea.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 312

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy suddenly starts choking while eating peanuts. He is unable to speak, has severe respiratory distress, and is clutching his throat. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Heimlich manoeuvre

 

This is a classic case of upper airway obstruction due to a foreign body in the larynx or upper trachea. The Heimlich manoeuvre (abdominal thrusts) is the first-line and life-saving intervention in such situations. It works by increasing intrathoracic pressure, helping dislodge the foreign body.

 

It is the immediate first-aid measure in a choking child/adult with complete airway obstruction.

 

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Rigid bronchoscopy under general anesthesia: Not the first step. It is done in a controlled setting if Heimlich fails or if obstruction is lower down.

 

Option C. Oral suctioning: Ineffective if the obstruction is at the level of the larynx or trachea and the object is not visible.

 

Option D. Start oxygen via face mask: Cannot bypass the obstructed airway. Oxygenation will not be effective until the foreign body is removed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heimlich manoeuvre is the immediate life-saving intervention in cases of complete upper airway obstruction due to a foreign body.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 323

questions.text: A 45-year-old male chronic smoker presents with hoarseness of voice for the past 3 months. Indirect laryngoscopy (I/L) is performed in the outpatient department using a warmed laryngeal mirror. Which of the following structures is LEAST likely to be visualized on indirect laryngoscopy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior commissure

 

  • Indirect laryngoscopy (I/L) is a basic ENT examination tool using a small mirror held at the back of the throat. Though vocal cords and posterior laryngeal structures can be visualized, certain areas cannot be seen clearly due to their anatomical position or overhanging structures.
  • The anterior commissure, laryngeal surface of epiglottis, ventricle, and subglottis are poorly visualized or missed on I/L examination.

 

Lies at the most anterior point of glottis and is often obscured due to angle and overhang of epiglottis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior commissure: Visible during I/L; lies at the posterior end between the arytenoids.

 

Option B. Vocal cords: Well-visualized, especially during phonation.

 

Option D. Arytenoids: Easily seen as they lie posteriorly and are prominent during examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indirect laryngoscopy may miss anterior commissure, subglottis, ventricle, and laryngeal surface of epiglottis due to limited visualization.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 384

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is scheduled for endaural tympanoplasty. During preparation, the operating microscope is set up for optimal magnification and working distance. What is the most appropriate focal length of the microscope lens for this ear surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 200 mm

 

  • ENT operating microscopes are essential tools that provide magnification and illumination during microsurgical procedures. The focal length determines the working distance between the microscope lens and the surgical field:
    • 200 mm – Optimal for ear surgeries (e.g., tympanoplasty, mastoidectomy), as these require high magnification and a short working distance.
    • 300 mm – Preferred for nasal surgeries to allow more room for instruments.
    • 400 mm – Used in throat surgeries, where a greater distance is needed for endoscopic or microscopic access.

 

Standard for ear surgeries due to precise visual and instrument control requirements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 100 mm: Too short for any practical ENT procedure; would severely limit instrument movement.

 

Option C. 300 mm: Used for nasal surgeries, not ideal for ear procedures due to longer working distance.

 

Option D. 400 mm: Used in throat surgeries, would reduce magnification for ear procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A 200 mm focal length microscope lens is ideal for ear surgeries like tympanoplasty due to its high magnification and short working distance.

 

Ref: Olutoye OA, Watcha MF. Eyes, Ears, Nose, and Throat Surgery. Gregory's Pediatric Anesthesia. 2012 Feb 3:777-809.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the ENT clinic with a complaint of altered speech quality. The mother describes the child’s speech as muffled and lacking nasal resonance, especially when pronouncing nasal sounds like "m" and "n". Examination reveals enlarged adenoids partially obstructing the nasopharynx. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rhinolalia clausa

 

  • Rhinolalia clausa refers to hyponasal speech due to mechanical obstruction of the nasal passage or nasopharynx, such as with nasal polyps, adenoids, or nasal tumors. Sounds like “m” and “n” may sound like “b” and “d”, respectively.
  • Rhinolalia aperta, on the other hand, involves hypernasal speech caused by an incomplete closure of the velopharyngeal port, leading to nasal air escape. Seen in cleft palate, velopharyngeal insufficiency, or post-adenoidectomy.

 

 

Caused by nasal or nasopharyngeal obstruction—in this case, enlarged adenoids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinolalia aperta: Hypernasality due to velopharyngeal dysfunction. Not consistent with adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option B. Velopharyngeal insufficiency: This causes hypernasality, not the hyponasal speech described.

 

Option D. Functional aphonia: No voice production due to psychogenic causes. Not relevant to nasal resonance issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinolalia clausa is a type of hyponasal speech caused by obstruction of the nasal cavity or nasopharynx, commonly seen with adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 315
